content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												Game has become a negative posterchild for pay to win. Before people who didn't spent any or just some money for slots etc. had a fighting chance. And even more importantly, they had some time to enjoy the game. Now they nerfed healing, so most Characters with healing skills get their healing only temporarily. Before, you could play 1-2 hours w/o a problem w/o having to use so called health packs.Now, w/o proper healing, after you used your 5 free healthpacks per day, which can easily happen after 2-3 games, as EACH hero (you can use 3 heroes at a time) needs to get healed with one pack. So after 3 games (maybe 10 minutes) you can easily run out of health packs and that was it for the day as it takes hours for the healthpacks to replenish. Most people won't have the time play for 10-20 minutes every 5 or so hours, because they work and basically have a life.If you wanted, like I did before, enjoy an hour or the occasional 2 hours on the couch, playing Dark Reign, you are now out of luck. After 30 minutes tops you run out of health packs and heroes to play. And guess how you only (reliably) get them back? Right, by purchasing them with real money. You can't even use the "normal" in-game currency.To level one hero to 50ish (of over 200 levels) costs about 90 € (NINETY), if you do this with currency from the real-money in-game shop.The most infuriating part is, that the devs think us stupid and lie to people, claiming the new system would save them time, because playing a 5 Minute game every few games to heal your heroes to full is much longer than waiting 5+ hours .TL;DR, it's a predatory business model aimed at addicted players who need to continue playing after they ran out of health packs. Keep away till they change that factor. If they do, the game can be fun.

number of helpful: 11 of 22 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2013
												The gameplay is so much fun - a great time killer. The same old Bejeweled/PQ basic mechanic of 'matching 3 gems or more' is there, a huge appeal for its fanbase. Also, with the quests system, there's a sense of progression unlike the old Bejeweled. You actually need to check your opponents level prior to accepting the quest, rearrange your roster, heal your heroes or arming the power ups to make things easier. In addition to great quests, we also have very decent graphic and badass OSTs. Granted that it's not AAA's 3D levels, but the detailed chars and charming designs are more than enough. The actual Heads Up Display is clear and concise, allowing players to reach the menu they want to use. There's also a simple descriptions to each of heroes' powers so you can understand what you're going to invoke before deciding (since the point placement is permanent and not respecable).The video options are barebones, but really there's no need Anti Aliasing and those fancy Physx Tesselation whatever it's called options. You can use your native resolutions - at least that's commonly used nowadays - to prevent screen tearing. Well, in my case, it autodetected everything so it's click and play.Game performance overall is silky smooth even on my mid-end rig. Transitions between scenes are quite short, no boring loading screen that takes ages to finish and so far zero crash.Now after all good stuffs, here comes the problem, microtransactions. In order to upgrade your heroes within reasonable timeframe, you need to either be lucky with rewards rolls, or grind the best rewarding quess repeatedly, or purchasing DLCs. That's where the major problem is. All would have been a little better if the quest rewards can make up for it so free players don't have to bang against the wall out of frustration.Multiplayer is missing, but I'd imagine it'd be great to have a match up against other people real time matching gems together.Great Free to Play game ridden by micro transactions. It's a real shame, the game has a chance to be other FTP killers on Steam, but severely missed it. In the end though, I'd play until I am tired with the brick wall that prevents me from advancing, or bored.

content:
Posted: January 15, 2015
												I enjoy match-3 games, and this comes with all of the benefits and drawbacks that come with competitive versions. (Matches aren't timed, but opponents take alternating turns against you, with possibilities for long strings of watching the computer play when it gets a lucky combo.) The game makes full use of 4- and 5-matches, giving each a different bonus, and recognizing T-shaped and L-shaped 5-matches. (Games that don't do this drive me crazy.)As a free-to-play game, I like that everything in-game is still accessible without purchase. Progression is a bit slower, of course, but it is possible to win "hero points" (in-game gold) and expand the slots available for heroes.The unique elements of this game are two-fold:1) A collectable card-game like element of choosing which heroes to keep and level up, and which combinations to use in each battle.2) A chance for gamers not already steeped in superhero lore to get to know Marvel characters and interactions a bit better. It's quickly turning me into a fan!There are two modes of play: "story mode" and "versus". * Story mode has in-character intro and outro dialog, pulling you into a comic storyline. It's a fun way to immerse yourself in the lore of the Marvel universe. * Versus mode pits your selection of heroes against heroes from another player's roster. It is worth noting that you are not actually playing the other person, but rather the AI using their heroes and abilities. This is a huge positive for me, because I don't have to deal with connection lags, people who afk for long periods, or trolling in a chat window. But if you're looking to match wits against a human opponent, this might leaving you wanting for more. Over 40 hours in, this continues to be a deeply engaging game!

content:

												My first review, i'm so excited. Lets begin:This game is very addictive , it's one of those games where you are always checking back and forward to see what's happened next. There are roughly 11 events per season(a season lasting 24 days give or take) and we are on season 10. Events lasting 3 days, straight after each other.Unfortunately this game has some incredibly frustrating flaws such as an unfair, unbalanced ranking system where you can get attacked for a frustrating 110 points(that's like dying 10 times straight in COD by just spawning) and superiority anxiety meaning the guy with the best characters' wins.While this game has a very large roster, it has very little little access to them. There are roughly 60 playable characters but few ways to get them.You get fan favorites like Deadpool, Nick fury and wolverine, Rocket & Groot, Avengers and many more, you even get obscure characters such as Venom, juggernaut, Daken(wolverines son), beast, black panther, Blade(yip - surprised to) , Daredevil, The hood(see in game) , Ragnarok(there's an upcoming movie - thor's clone) and even a dinosaur called devil dinosaur.You get characters from the x men universe (beast, mystique, storm, magneto etc), avengers (all from 2012 movie), guardians of the galaxy (so far rocket/groot, Gamora), fantastic four and more. While this game is not perfect, anyone who loves marvel and knows nearly everything about marvel should definitely play this game(free).  They currently on "Marvel now" and “Dark reign” story lines. So they very current as these are very recent storylines in the MU.Thanx please comment on my review.Thanks Dragon Priest

												It's a fun, strategic match-3 game with Marvel elements. The game is currently running during the Dark Reign period Marvel had. From what I gather, it's following that storyline pretty good. As for the game, there is a good source of strategy to matching your colors, gaining AP (attack points) to get your heroes to use their special abilities. There are anywhere from 2-3 abilities for each hero and some of them 0-2 of them could be passive based on the hero/villian you get. Each hero also gains their powers through "covers" and each of these can be strengthend to a power of 5. As you gain more covers, you can then increase your heroes level as well. All-in-all, I enjoy playing the game in short burts on my android for the most part.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
												Do you enjoy Marvel superheroes?  Do you enjoy matching threes?  Do you enjoy not paying for games?  Well, then, perhaps you should try Marvel Puzzle Quest, a free-to-play match three game featuring Marvel superheroes.Conceptually, MPQ is quite simple.  You pit your team of three superheroes against another team of three superheroes or villains and take turns rearranging coloured tiles to match lines of three or more in classic Bejeweled fashion.  The twist here is each superhero has at least one (and up to three) super powers they can use to affect the tide of the battle.  Each tile you match on the board adds coloured "action points" to your reserve, which in turn fuel your heroes' powers.  So after you've banked 9 blue action points, you can use Black Widow's ability to stun her opponent, giving you a couple free moves, 10 green action points will let you use Storm's lightning ability to smash a bunch of random tiles, and so on.  While some powers can really turn the tide of the battle if used effectively, many are just lame.   Would you rather have an ability that changes the colour of a few tiles, or simply clobbers your opponent for 1000 points of damage?  Yeah, me too.  The game is split into two basic modes, Story mode and Versus mode.  In the former, you're following a sort of simplistic campaign, punctuated by a series of really lame cutscenes involving no animation,  a single background, and some cringe-inducing dialogue.  In the latter, you're sort of going head-to-head with another player's team, except not really, because the computer is actually controlling their moves.  The AI is generally not very strategic, and will often make mistakes such as creating a tile that benefits itself, then immediately destroying it.  Two "currencies" fuel your efforts; Hero Points and ISO-88, used to both buy new heroes and upgrade their powers.  Unsurprisingly, you can buy either of them by ponying up some real life cash.  I'm not sure why anyone would do this.  The real fun of MPQ – at least for me – was earning points to buy new heroes and then upgrading their powers.  So the option to simply buy as many points as I want would pretty much nullify most of my enjoyment of the game.  Unfortunately, even if you do spend some big bucks on the game, you still can't just buy whichever hero you want; you're just paying for random card drops and hoping the card you want is somewhere out there.  Even worse, if you finally DO get one of the more rare heroes, you won't even be able to use all their powers unless you find more rare cards to upgrade them.  You can theoretically earn more Hero Points and ISO-88 by replaying old missions, but quite often you'll get some lame 20 point reward instead of the juicy rewards you were promised.  Marvel Puzzle Quest has fine production values.  The art is bright, colourful and well-done but the animation is very minimal.  This is most noticeable when using the superheroes' powers, some of which look nice, but many of which look really lame.  Likewise, the music is great, but repeats constantly.  Voice overs would've added some more personality to the proceedings, but it's pretty clear this was not a big budget game. So why would anyone want to play this game?  Well, for starters, it's free.  And the classic match three gameplay has timeless appeal.  Unfortunately, for all its trappings, MPQ really is just a match three game.  So no matter how much strategy or tactics you attempt to throw at it, you're still at the mercy of whatever coloured tiles drop from the sky.  And you'll still lose matches because the AI somehow managed to get an unstoppable chain reaction of matches, with devastating results.   Even without spending a dime on the game, I managed to beat all the story missions and place fairly well in the versus events.  And for some of the many hours I spent, I was actually having a blast.  Marvel Puzzle Quest has the sort of gameplay that's strategic enough to be engaging, but not complex enough to keep you up all night. As long as you keep winning, it keeps doling out a steady stream of upgrade points and "recruit tokens" you might be able to turn into a new hero for your roster.  It's not a game anyone should spend money on, but if you like matching threes... hey, did I mention it's free?

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
												Very fun, and not very pay-to-win like all the reviews say.The PvE story roughly follows the Dark Reign comics, with Norman Osborn, the Green Goblin, creating the subtlely-named Dark Avengers, of which Bullseye is the best by far, in order to do something for someone, I don't know. He is opposed by Iron Man, Black Widow, Storm, Hawkeye, Wolverine, and Thor. It ends with a fairly high level boss fight, which can be easily beaten with stuns or heal abuse because it's a three-on-one curbstomp.After that, you can go through weekly events against other players to earn more ISO-8, which is your experience, or Hero Points, which can get you more slots for more characters. Most of these events have restrictions or characters that get bonuses in stats, encouraging you to use them in your team and keep the characters you're not as interested in.I haven't seen the pay-to-win much in my time of playing. Even if you buy ISO-8 and Hero Points, you're still going to have to keep up against people who have more experience with their characters than you and can set up teams with better gem coverage. And even if you get a full party of rare characters, they don't all work together as well as the lower level characters, and many of the three star characters have weaknesses to their powers, such as Iron Man Model 40's Recharge, which provides gems to use on other attacks, but stuns Iron Man for two turns.Overall, I enjoy this a good bit, and recommend it to others.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												Certainly a pay to win game, there’s no doubt about that, however the game still offers a fun and challenging experience by not even paying at all. You can still experience the full game without spending a dime; all you need is patience and skill. The game may have a dull story but the gameplay of solving puzzles and collecting characters is highly addictive and entertaining. The best aspect of MPQ:DR is that you don’t need to play it a lot in a day; just having a 30 minute session can get you tonnes of rewards and still build a decent team without having to even look at any micro transactions. Overall, I find the game very fun to play and it’s great to burn a few hours a week with addictive and enjoyable puzzle solving. 8/10

content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
												Yes it's a little harsh on it's free to play claim, but the game itself is great. With Marvel's vast collection of heroes and villains, once they are able to add more characters, it will be even better. If you pay what you would a normal game, it gives you a head start, but as long as you participate you should get a ton of free crystals just by doing the missions and repeatables. In the beginning I found Thor, Wolverine and Juggernaut to be especially useful in various teams, all 3 are extremely resilient and in the earlier stages of the game Juggernaut's red ability can usually one shot any enemy. I've gotten both Magnetos and The Hood from just basic recruit tokens so you can get lucky there as well. Favorite character so far is 3 star Magneto.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2014
												A lot of people seem to moan about microtransactions, but for me the game really is a blast, and I've spent only about 3 euro (SHIELD's recruit pack, discounted at the time) to get more space for additional characters. While it doesn't seem so at first, there's suprising depth to the strategy - you need to balance your team so that you can use every color of tiles and have the stronger characters cover the weaker ones (so be careful not to overlevel your support, like Storm, to the point where she takes the spot in front of your Wolverine and gets promptly chewed in three turns). Don't expect long playing sessions because of the helath regeneration system, but the deafault heal time plus 5 regenerating health packs usually allow you to play three-four games every two hours or so. And honestly, it's a match three game, so you'd become bored with more. Great for breaks at work and extra nice if you are a Marvel fan, I appreciate the use of comic book covers as skill icons. Shame about the absence of Steam Cloud support, though.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2013
												Marvel Puzzle Quest is a tipical block combining game that adds to the game the marvel universe/heroes to give some diversity and fun collecting/leveling the heroes.Every heroe has diferent habilities and you can fight in 3v3 battles combining the strenghts of your heroes to progress through the game. You start with 3 basic heroes after doing the tutorial and you have to manage to lvl up using the ISO points you obtain by winning battles. Some battles on the campaign gives you extra heroes or hero points (hero points are the ones you need to have extra slots for more heroes).Its a bit slow at the beginning because every time a hero takes damages, it needs time to restore his hp, so whe you have only 3 heroes it can be a bit slow to advance. But as soon as you have 5+ heroes and reach lvl 10+ with some of them, you can keep playing almost indefinitly without having to spend real money on the game. Paying real money on this game only gives you a faster progression, but you can manage to do everything just by playing the game.If you like puzzle games its worth to try this one, just have in mind the first few hours are a bit slow if you dont invest real money.

												If you can get past the microtransactions, this game is pretty good. Assembling a team makes things interesting, as each hero and villain have unique attacks. number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												Very fun puzzle quest variant! The puzzle mechanic is excellent, and team creation is dynamic and enjoyable. Rewards are meaningful, and collecting the "comic covers" (i.e., leveling your Heros) is very fun.It is also an excellent implementation of both free to play and micro transactions. Spending real money is by no means necessary, and although it speeds up your progress it does not make you more powerful than equal leveled players who have not spent money. The primary use for real money is to buy extra character slots, but you can earn the necessary currency by playing in the campaign or the semi-PvP daily and weekly events. Although a number of other reviewers have voiced dislike for the time based healing system, I actually really like it. Taking damage to your Heroes is bad, and the game is more enjoyable because of this difficulty backed up with a real penalty! I have yet to spend any real money on the game, and yet have played a ton and enjoyed it.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 20, 2014
												If you have any interest in super heroes, and collecting stuff then this game is for you. Don't heed people who say it's micro transactions galore. You can play without paying. Everyday there are several multiplayer events in which you can participate for free and win lots of Iso-8 and HP (game's more valuable other currency) if you are successful enough. There is also a huge single player campaign with lots of rewards. I don't know what people are complaining about. There is one thing though. If you are very competitive then you might feel you need to pay to get ahead of others. It will only save you game play time. Others will catch up to you if you pay, but it will take a while. Since I enjoy the game as it is and I'm a casual gamer at heart, I enjoy it a lot. The game is addictive. I also played old Puzzle Quest: Challenge of the Warlords. I had enjoyed that one though I didn't finish it. This is a bit different from that one in how leveling works and the fact that you don't have a single character to play with. From what I heard, game's support team is very efficient. I didn't have any problems with the game so far though.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 12, 2014
												I'm having fun. On the surface, it's a simple colour matching game. Easy, right? Anyone can do it. As a Hard Core Casual gamer, I really appreciate that. No timer, no hand eye coordination and instant decision making required. Yeay!It's also "Free to play" or supposed to be. Don't believe it! It's addictive. Like... like... shopping for a shopaholic. I'm a shopaholic. Having said that, I'm well aware of my gaming budget limitations. So i've spent enough on this game to buy a PS4 or so my friend tells me. I don't really care since there are no games on a PS4 that I can actually play and my PS3 works just fine. The games on my Playstation watchlist are all coming out on PS3 anyway. So, my game budget can handle this. I just wish Steam would stop blocking me, all the time. I'm nowhere near $2000.00 in 24 hours.Anyway, back to the game... Past the surface there are strategies and tactics that make the battles interesting. Different enemies change the feel and style of play required to win and so it keeps being fun. It's very grindy if your gaming budget or Steam doesn't allow you to buy what you need to level up your characters. BUT if you're not a PVP ♥♥♥♥♥ it doesn't really matter. Take your time, wind down after work with a game or two and eventually in a few... errr... years... ^_~ you'll get there eventually. I've only been playing for a few weeks, but I've paid for my character levels in cash. You get a present everyday you do play a game or two and if you care to play in the PVP arena, the rewards are more consistant than in the PVE games where the reward randomiser can give you the minimum reward heaps before surrendering the good stuff. It seems to be getting better, but that might just be my imagination. I didn't collect any data to compare last week's drops to this week's.The only downside at the moment is that the PVE content seems very limited. There's a Prologue which I have completed, though not obtained all the rewards and no sign of "Chapter 1". There are PVE Events, but because they are of limited time... go on holidays without your computer and you miss them.  If your team isn't at a sufficiently high level, you may only be able to complete the first few fights before the opponents get too hard to fight. Then you're stuck grinding those same few fights, your team can manage, to get enough points to reap the rewards on offer in the time that the Event is on for. There's even PVP Events - lots more of these, with Lightning Rounds and Tournaments you have to pay to play in.  I'm not much of a PVP player and once the teams I have to fight get too hard as my ranking climbs, I lose interest until I can level up my characters to get a chance at winning again. BUT by then the PVP Event, is over. Hmmm....I'm much more interested in Chapter 1 and the continuation of the Story started in the Prologue. Don't tell me they continued the story in past Events, cause I wasn't there to play them and when do they become Chapter 1?That's the MAJOR downside of this game. There doesn't seem to be anything beyond the Prologue.So you ask yourself why I'm recommending this game? Because I'm having FUN! Read a few other reviews and the forums and there are all kinds of grumbles about its inadequacies. BUT when all is said and done, it is a FUN game. It is an easy game to pick up and play, and once you get started, the character and power combinations become intriguing. It gets addictive simply because someone like me whats to collect them all and see how well, or not, they work together.I might wish for more permanent content... maybe there will be. I can only hope. In the mean time I'll be having fun with what is there.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												Fun game, but it feels better suited to tablets and shouldn't have been ported to PC. A lot if issues that other people are having can be lessen by playing in short sessions, such at 10 to 30 minutes at a time, especially with free heroes that the game will give you every few days, as well as cash shop currancy. With this game being on PC, we're acustomed to playing an hour or more, and this game penalizes that without using cash.One new game mechanic added to the Puzzle Quest system are abilities that effect tiles on the board. Such as Iron Man placing Protect Tiles, that turn the normal gems in to shielded gems to reduce damage to your heroes, or Storm's Attack Tiles that damage your opponent. They still behave like normal gems, in that you can match them to other colors and they'll go away. Some of your enemies also place gems that have a count down timer, and will activate after a number of turns have pasted. Like HAMMER Assassins that will place Sniper Tiles on the board, and will deal heavy damage to your heros after a few turns have passed. This helps you as a player, since you can prevent the enemies abilities by matching those countdown tiles, and removing the ability before it has a chance to go off.The worst part about this game, is that when your heroes are damaged or knocked out in a game, they will have to recover and this can take up to an hour or more without using heal packs. You start out with a dozen or so, but once you run out, you'll have to pay cash for more. Also, improving your hero is terrible. Instead of earning experience in battles, you earn this ISO-8 currancy, and you spend that on heroes to improve their base health and a few other stats. To improve their abilities, you have to either spend a ton of the premium currancy or hope that you get another copy of that hero. Say you have Captain America, and he only has one ability. To unlock his other 2 abilities, you'll need another Captain America, with that ability, and add his to your hero. It requires too much luck to improve just one hero, and Puzzle Quest's bosses are betting that will pay tons of money to do so.Yes, this game has a lot of options to get ahead with cash purchases, and these purchases won't go very far, since most of them are completely random. Say you really want Spider-man on your team, then you have to option of fighting Venom to win a Spider-man with a Fantastic Four suit or throw a few dollars at random hero packs and pray he turns up.I do recommend this game for tablets, since it's best suit to short play sessions.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 28, 2016
												I'm not one to be suckered in my free games usually, but having enjoyed games like Bejewelled and Puzzle Quest in the past, I figured I'd give it a try. At first, I played a few times, and then stopped playing for a few months as I wasn't sure if it was really my thing or not. I'm not sure what made me decide to try it again one day, but as you can no doubt tell from the hours I've got recorded playing this game, I kinda liked it... just a little ;) It's likely that it was the whole 'feemium' thing that turned me off to start, but this game is generous enough to make you want to keep playing without NEEDING to spend money.I've never been a comic fanatic or anything, but I've always enjoyed the characters from the Marvel universe, and loved watching the old cartoons like X-Men. Over the years I've been playing this game, I have spent the odd bit of cash here and there, but I don't think the amount I've spent would only come to around $30 I'd say. The team at D3 are continually adding new features and characters which keep my interest, and I am a member of an alliance with a group of firends who play, which makes it a little more fun, being able to discuss things with the group. It also allows you to get extra bonuses, as when your alliance members do well in events, the whole alliance will get rewards.This is a great game to play while having my morning coffee, as it's quick, yet rewarding, but at times during certain events, can be brutally difficult (Damn ninjas!! *shakes fist*). It wouldn't be much fun if it was a walk in the park though!It's also great that they have daily events, which keeps me coming back to see what's new and what else I can get! (This unlocks after you've played through a certain amount of the single player, so don't give up too soon!)If you've ever played match 3 games, and enjoyed them, I can't recommend this one highly enough. Building up an ever expanding roster of characters as fun as the game itself! In my opinion, it's by far the best of all the Puzzle Quest games that have been released, and I even though I have spent many years playing this game, I can't see myself stopping any time soon!I notice a lot of people don't recommend this based on their not being able to sync with their mobile version, but I've only ever played on Steam, and as such, I haven't come across any of those issues. They seem to say that they're given in game currency for free (Hero Points), but you can also get that in the PC version. Perhaps the amounts you get are different or something? I don't know as I've never played the mobile one, so if you only plan to play on PC, don't let that deter you, as you can get free HP in this version too.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 3, 2014
												Okay, so this clearly isn't a Triple A title but it can still be good right? Right?The answer is no. It isn't. It has good elements of fun. It's fairly entertaining as you gather new heroes, upgrade the ones you like, have cool and sometimes very useful special attacks. So what's the issue then? It's boring and poorly made.Well first off, the game is basically a Mobile Game ported to PC without ANY of the things a PC port should have. It doesn't have a resolution that would be fitting for a PC and instead looks like you're playing a Tablet game on your monitor. While that may not sound that bad, I've noticed even some of the UI choices are still touch screen like. It overall feels down right aweful to look at for extended periods of time.Next is the gameplay itself, it's very barebones as the best animations you will see is the little Gems going POOF from chain completions. The special attacks consit of your character of choice flying into the center of the screen and waggling a bit with some flashing lights and sounds.Once you figure out if you can enjoy the gameplay or not comes the ways you upgrade your heroes. It's basically random lottery as you have to get another copy of your hero to upgrade their skills, after which you then need to use ISO-8 the magical nonsense item to then increase their level. You also can only have so many heroes before you need to purchase more slots. Now that isn't too bad as it's normal, the problem is you can only use what is basically a "Money" currency which is limited as you only get some per day unless you wish to pay for it. The same currency is used for pretty much everything and they will try their damnedest to get you to waste it on heroes, upgrades, level increases, etc. Then they shoehorn in some Healing character nonsense that basically ripped off from Facebook games.The story missions try ever so hard to entertain and keep you interested but the lack of voices, new images and basically an interesting story that hasn't been heard over and over again, brings it down on its knees. The more interesting and rewarding stories are locked out until you play and gather Strong/OP heroes. It's not even recommended that you try them WHATSOEVER until you're very well off into the game as they will not only stomp you out but cause you to need "Health packs" just to recover and continue playing the game. The next part of story missions is that they often can be replayed for different loot, the problem is even though it says 1/4 things to be looted you can still gain something that ISN'T an option as loot. I've gotten ISO-20 which wasn't an option instead of ISO-100 or another Iron Man. When all you do is want to have 4/4 in loot and you have to replay the same, easy, boring level repeatedly just to make sure you have everything useful from that mission, it gets very boring.The art direction is okay at best; you have art work that doesn't look the best on these big screens as it's made for much smaller ones. The characters don't have the best animations as they seem more and more like paper cutouts than they do powerful superheroes. It's pretty underwhelming watching them play out an unskippable animation.The sound is basically the same as the art direction, bland, boring and not that interesting. I was really hoping for some good Marvel action tunes.In short, the game starts off okay but slowly turns into a long road through Pay to Play. Not too bad if played in short, short bursts but very boring if you're going to play for hours at a time.3 Broken Gems out of 10.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 30, 2015
												Cons:~ Monetized, and not well. Darn near everything costs and you will never have enough of whatever to do the job. ~ Rewards you cannot use until you pay or earn premium currency for the space to claim it.~ Time-Based System would be acceptable if it were shorter.Pros:~ Puzzle Quest Series' infamous "Stacking the Deck against you in place of intelligent opponents" difficulty system seems to have been abandoned. You get lucky drops of new gems just as often as the CPU does. Defeat is not decided for you in advance.~ Interesting improvement system, despite monetization angle.~ Guild system and game modes that reward you for acting together, though apart (sharing powers, guild-wide rewards in their special events). Makes many good things you get into benefits you can share (such as your great high-level card being sent out as a backup to allies).Play it. Cautiously.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
												Yes it's a little harsh on it's free to play claim, but the game itself is great. With Marvel's vast collection of heroes and villains, once they are able to add more characters, it will be even better. If you pay what you would a normal game, it gives you a head start, but as long as you participate you should get a ton of free crystals just by doing the missions and repeatables. In the beginning I found Thor, Wolverine and Juggernaut to be especially useful in various teams, all 3 are extremely resilient and in the earlier stages of the game Juggernaut's red ability can usually one shot any enemy. I've gotten both Magnetos and The Hood from just basic recruit tokens so you can get lucky there as well. Favorite character so far is 3 star Magneto.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7, 2014
												A lot of people seem to moan about microtransactions, but for me the game really is a blast, and I've spent only about 3 euro (SHIELD's recruit pack, discounted at the time) to get more space for additional characters. While it doesn't seem so at first, there's suprising depth to the strategy - you need to balance your team so that you can use every color of tiles and have the stronger characters cover the weaker ones (so be careful not to overlevel your support, like Storm, to the point where she takes the spot in front of your Wolverine and gets promptly chewed in three turns). Don't expect long playing sessions because of the helath regeneration system, but the deafault heal time plus 5 regenerating health packs usually allow you to play three-four games every two hours or so. And honestly, it's a match three game, so you'd become bored with more. Great for breaks at work and extra nice if you are a Marvel fan, I appreciate the use of comic book covers as skill icons. Shame about the absence of Steam Cloud support, though.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 18, 2013
												Marvel Puzzle Quest is a tipical block combining game that adds to the game the marvel universe/heroes to give some diversity and fun collecting/leveling the heroes.Every heroe has diferent habilities and you can fight in 3v3 battles combining the strenghts of your heroes to progress through the game. You start with 3 basic heroes after doing the tutorial and you have to manage to lvl up using the ISO points you obtain by winning battles. Some battles on the campaign gives you extra heroes or hero points (hero points are the ones you need to have extra slots for more heroes).Its a bit slow at the beginning because every time a hero takes damages, it needs time to restore his hp, so whe you have only 3 heroes it can be a bit slow to advance. But as soon as you have 5+ heroes and reach lvl 10+ with some of them, you can keep playing almost indefinitly without having to spend real money on the game. Paying real money on this game only gives you a faster progression, but you can manage to do everything just by playing the game.If you like puzzle games its worth to try this one, just have in mind the first few hours are a bit slow if you dont invest real money.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2013
												The game is pretty fun, at first, then it gets incredibly frustrating seeing how many people are , from the look of it, months and months ahead of you..except that some actually pay for progress. You don't really have to pay if you don't mind moving along in a snail's pace, but you'll get there, eventually. They started requiring that you use certain characters to be able to progress through certain events in order to finish in a good place (good place has better rewards etc etc) , so you either won that specificy character last event, or you purchased it, or you are pretty much destined to finish in a place other than first throughout the event.You can also link up the mobile version with this one so you can play the same account on both devices, takes a few days to get them synced, however, it took them 8 days to sync mine.It's a nice game, though, hopefully they balance it out between F2P and P2W.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												Very fun puzzle quest variant! The puzzle mechanic is excellent, and team creation is dynamic and enjoyable. Rewards are meaningful, and collecting the "comic covers" (i.e., leveling your Heros) is very fun.It is also an excellent implementation of both free to play and micro transactions. Spending real money is by no means necessary, and although it speeds up your progress it does not make you more powerful than equal leveled players who have not spent money. The primary use for real money is to buy extra character slots, but you can earn the necessary currency by playing in the campaign or the semi-PvP daily and weekly events. Although a number of other reviewers have voiced dislike for the time based healing system, I actually really like it. Taking damage to your Heroes is bad, and the game is more enjoyable because of this difficulty backed up with a real penalty! I have yet to spend any real money on the game, and yet have played a ton and enjoyed it.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 20, 2014
												If you have any interest in super heroes, and collecting stuff then this game is for you. Don't heed people who say it's micro transactions galore. You can play without paying. Everyday there are several multiplayer events in which you can participate for free and win lots of Iso-8 and HP (game's more valuable other currency) if you are successful enough. There is also a huge single player campaign with lots of rewards. I don't know what people are complaining about. There is one thing though. If you are very competitive then you might feel you need to pay to get ahead of others. It will only save you game play time. Others will catch up to you if you pay, but it will take a while. Since I enjoy the game as it is and I'm a casual gamer at heart, I enjoy it a lot. The game is addictive. I also played old Puzzle Quest: Challenge of the Warlords. I had enjoyed that one though I didn't finish it. This is a bit different from that one in how leveling works and the fact that you don't have a single character to play with. From what I heard, game's support team is very efficient. I didn't have any problems with the game so far though.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
												If you can get past the microtransactions, this game is pretty good. Assembling a team makes things interesting, as each hero and villain have unique attacks. Matching 4 in a row no longer gives you another turn like it did in the original, but instead clears out the whole row or column. And Marvel is Marvel. If you're willing to pay for the vanilla Puzzle Quest, I'd recommend playing that instead.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 12, 2014
												I'm having fun. On the surface, it's a simple colour matching game. Easy, right? Anyone can do it. As a Hard Core Casual gamer, I really appreciate that. No timer, no hand eye coordination and instant decision making required. Yeay!It's also "Free to play" or supposed to be. Don't believe it! It's addictive. Like... like... shopping for a shopaholic. I'm a shopaholic. Having said that, I'm well aware of my gaming budget limitations. So i've spent enough on this game to buy a PS4 or so my friend tells me. I don't really care since there are no games on a PS4 that I can actually play and my PS3 works just fine. The games on my Playstation watchlist are all coming out on PS3 anyway. So, my game budget can handle this. I just wish Steam would stop blocking me, all the time. I'm nowhere near $2000.00 in 24 hours.Anyway, back to the game... Past the surface there are strategies and tactics that make the battles interesting. Different enemies change the feel and style of play required to win and so it keeps being fun. It's very grindy if your gaming budget or Steam doesn't allow you to buy what you need to level up your characters. BUT if you're not a PVP ♥♥♥♥♥ it doesn't really matter. Take your time, wind down after work with a game or two and eventually in a few... errr... years... ^_~ you'll get there eventually. I've only been playing for a few weeks, but I've paid for my character levels in cash. You get a present everyday you do play a game or two and if you care to play in the PVP arena, the rewards are more consistant than in the PVE games where the reward randomiser can give you the minimum reward heaps before surrendering the good stuff. It seems to be getting better, but that might just be my imagination. I didn't collect any data to compare last week's drops to this week's.The only downside at the moment is that the PVE content seems very limited. There's a Prologue which I have completed, though not obtained all the rewards and no sign of "Chapter 1". There are PVE Events, but because they are of limited time... go on holidays without your computer and you miss them.  If your team isn't at a sufficiently high level, you may only be able to complete the first few fights before the opponents get too hard to fight. Then you're stuck grinding those same few fights, your team can manage, to get enough points to reap the rewards on offer in the time that the Event is on for. There's even PVP Events - lots more of these, with Lightning Rounds and Tournaments you have to pay to play in.  I'm not much of a PVP player and once the teams I have to fight get too hard as my ranking climbs, I lose interest until I can level up my characters to get a chance at winning again. BUT by then the PVP Event, is over. Hmmm....I'm much more interested in Chapter 1 and the continuation of the Story started in the Prologue. Don't tell me they continued the story in past Events, cause I wasn't there to play them and when do they become Chapter 1?That's the MAJOR downside of this game. There doesn't seem to be anything beyond the Prologue.So you ask yourself why I'm recommending this game? Because I'm having FUN! Read a few other reviews and the forums and there are all kinds of grumbles about its inadequacies. BUT when all is said and done, it is a FUN game. It is an easy game to pick up and play, and once you get started, the character and power combinations become intriguing. It gets addictive simply because someone like me whats to collect them all and see how well, or not, they work together.I might wish for more permanent content... maybe there will be. I can only hope. In the mean time I'll be having fun with what is there.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												This game gets a bad rep.. and mostly because people are cheap.  Here's my take on it:I know my "time played" only says a little over an hour.  But I've easily put 10+ hours into the iPhone version.  And I've never had to spend a dime.  It's a game you can EASILY play for 30 minutes, then come back to, rinse and repeat.  And you would never need to spend money.  I've done very well in the iPhone version and never bought anything from the store.For the PC players.. the game is free.  FREE.  What do you expect for Free?  Have you ever worked at a software company?  Probably not.  Any developer of software would be out of business in a month if they just gave you free games that never asked for micro-transactions.  All you have to do is click the X and move on.Personally, when I tried the PC version, I enjoyed it.  It's pretty much the exact same game, but without the limiting frames of the smart phone versions.  Very big and bright.  But otherwise identical.  It's Bejeweled, and every once in a while a Marvel Hero artwork jumps out and throws some particle effects around.Cons?  Yeah, there are definitely some.  This is a VERY cash shop oriented game that will remind you at every turn that you can buy tokens, iso-8, characters, covers, etc etc etc.  But like most games of this ilk, you can get around that if you don't suck at it, and use your resources wisely.  Sure, there's a bit of luck involved.. and God forbid you would have to spend $5-10 to support the developer of a game you got FOR FREE.  My only other gripe is that the smart phone version of it doesn't sync with the steam version.. it really sucks having to start over when playing it on PC, when I have a bad♥♥♥♥♥team on my phone.In the end, I give this a 8/10.  It's no Puzzle Quest 2 (but what is) and all I can say is that if money is that big of a problem for you, then video games shouldn't be your hobby.  Maybe get a better job.  :)

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2014
												I forgot I had already written a review for this so thought I'd write one... in doing so I came across a lot of negative reviews for this game and I actually don't think they are quite deserved.Yes you can "pay to win" in this game... but you can also progress reasonably without doing so... there is in fact strategy involved that can help you advance faster (namely when you start getting to the top of the leaderboard in challenges either only battle when your top heroes are healthy, or back off until you have health boosts to bring them back up to full strength otherwise you will fight your way back down the ladder through losses).It is true that your heroes take a long time to recover their health over time... but you also get health boosts (max 5 at a time unless you pick up a bonus pack then you can have more). I have not spent one coin on this game and have a healthy roster (not sure how many but it spans about three pages in side scrolling)... daily rewards and winning battles gives you enough to be able to buy more hero slots and the covers are actually random... I have now had a few high level gold card drops in just the "standard cover" category. It does seem as though sometimes the AI throws the opponent a much better board move than you... but if people are honest that can happen in their favour as well.Sure I've received enough Daken 1 stars to create an army... but that's the weighing of chance of the likelyhood of having a great character pop up. It's a game that I am quite happy to put a couple of hours in a day... play the matches I think I can win and slowly build my team.I suspect that most of the people annoyed at this game are ones with no patience who perhaps want everything now but don't want to pay for it. I'm happy to not pay for anything and take my time and just enjoy the game dynamics.A very worthy addition to the Puzzle Quest series. Great use of the Marvel Characters and very good at drawing you in to win the next battle. Well paced rewards and challenges.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												Certainly a pay to win game, there’s no doubt about that, however the game still offers a fun and challenging experience by not even paying at all. You can still experience the full game without spending a dime; all you need is patience and skill. The game may have a dull story but the gameplay of solving puzzles and collecting characters is highly addictive and entertaining. The best aspect of MPQ:DR is that you don’t need to play it a lot in a day; just having a 30 minute session can get you tonnes of rewards and still build a decent team without having to even look at any micro transactions. Overall, I find the game very fun to play and it’s great to burn a few hours a week with addictive and enjoyable puzzle solving. 8/10

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 28, 2016
												I'm not one to be suckered in my free games usually, but having enjoyed games like Bejewelled and Puzzle Quest in the past, I figured I'd give it a try. At first, I played a few times, and then stopped playing for a few months as I wasn't sure if it was really my thing or not. I'm not sure what made me decide to try it again one day, but as you can no doubt tell from the hours I've got recorded playing this game, I kinda liked it... just a little ;) It's likely that it was the whole 'feemium' thing that turned me off to start, but this game is generous enough to make you want to keep playing without NEEDING to spend money.I've never been a comic fanatic or anything, but I've always enjoyed the characters from the Marvel universe, and loved watching the old cartoons like X-Men. Over the years I've been playing this game, I have spent the odd bit of cash here and there, but I don't think the amount I've spent would only come to around $30 I'd say. The team at D3 are continually adding new features and characters which keep my interest, and I am a member of an alliance with a group of firends who play, which makes it a little more fun, being able to discuss things with the group. It also allows you to get extra bonuses, as when your alliance members do well in events, the whole alliance will get rewards.This is a great game to play while having my morning coffee, as it's quick, yet rewarding, but at times during certain events, can be brutally difficult (Damn ninjas!! *shakes fist*). It wouldn't be much fun if it was a walk in the park though!It's also great that they have daily events, which keeps me coming back to see what's new and what else I can get! (This unlocks after you've played through a certain amount of the single player, so don't give up too soon!)If you've ever played match 3 games, and enjoyed them, I can't recommend this one highly enough. Building up an ever expanding roster of characters as fun as the game itself! In my opinion, it's by far the best of all the Puzzle Quest games that have been released, and I even though I have spent many years playing this game, I can't see myself stopping any time soon!I notice a lot of people don't recommend this based on their not being able to sync with their mobile version, but I've only ever played on Steam, and as such, I haven't come across any of those issues. They seem to say that they're given in game currency for free (Hero Points), but you can also get that in the PC version. Perhaps the amounts you get are different or something? I don't know as I've never played the mobile one, so if you only plan to play on PC, don't let that deter you, as you can get free HP in this version too.

content:
Posted: March 3, 2014
												Whether you will like this game depends on what you are looking for in it. Most of the criticism of this game revolves around the 'pay to win' accusations, and in a sense they're true, you're unlikely to win most of the main events if you don't sink some money into buying new heroes, health packs or slots for new heroes, so if you're the kind of person who wants to open it up and play for hours non-stop without paying a thing this game will likely frustrate you. For me I didn't want to spend much on this game, I've spent a total of £6 after 100 hours playing and I don't intend to spend anymore. When I play I'm not in a rush and am happy to slowly build up my heroes over time, I play in shorter bursts to do certain events and can play in windowed mode to rotate it around with other things. Some people get annoyed because if you lose and have run out of health packs the only way to get more is to buy them or wait to win more in certain events. As for the actual gameplay, there's not much to say. You pick three of your heroes against opposition and match the colours up to best suit the abilities of your selected heroes. It's puzzlequest and free to try out if you're unsure. Also note that for the multiplayer you are not actually playing against other people, it is against three of their heroes that the ai controls.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2015
												Cons:~ Monetized, and not well. Darn near everything costs and you will never have enough of whatever to do the job. ~ Rewards you cannot use until you pay or earn premium currency for the space to claim it.~ Time-Based System would be acceptable if it were shorter.Pros:~ Puzzle Quest Series' infamous "Stacking the Deck against you in place of intelligent opponents" difficulty system seems to have been abandoned. You get lucky drops of new gems just as often as the CPU does. Defeat is not decided for you in advance.~ Interesting improvement system, despite monetization angle.~ Guild system and game modes that reward you for acting together, though apart (sharing powers, guild-wide rewards in their special events). Makes many good things you get into benefits you can share (such as your great high-level card being sent out as a backup to allies).Play it. Cautiously.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2014
												Let me get this out of the way: this is a very nice game. It combines match-3 with cardfight (not sure what they are called) games where you level up your cards. Here you level up your (Marvel) heroes by earning Iso-8 and by earning their skills.There are events that give you big prices (lots of Iso-8 or recruit tokens for more heroes).More heroes. That's why I wouldn't recomment this game. You start with roster of 4 heroes. For every extra hero you need to buy an extra slot for Gold. You guessed it, gold is real money.Four hero slots is nothing. I played less than a day and already had 10 heroes (5 rostered and 5 waiting to be recruited).If that part of the game was any different or if buying with real money doesn't bother you: play this game. It's nice. Good graphics, nice sound effects, good skills and there's even a storyline.For me however that's a dealbreaker. You will not progress enough if you do not buy extra roster space.So...byebye MPQ.

												It's a free to play, but pay to win.  You can try to grind it out but you won't really make much progress. The freebies were fun, but the cost to keep playing is not my idea of money well spent.  You have $10 sitting around?  Wait for a sale and get a good game you can keep playing over and over.  On the other hand, if this your thing, spending money and more money to play a "free game" so you can keep up, then go right ahead.  It's definitely not for me though.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
												I think I've given the game a decent chance. It is kind of hard to rate, though; it's fun enough to play casually, but it makes casual play difficult with its problematic scaling that so often doesn't work and a level system that is completely dysfunctional.It really tries super-hard for microtransactions, which I understand are helpful to the developers, but good grief. When the game itself is made less fun and, more importantly, less functional for the sake of encouraging pay-to-win (or at least, pay to have more of a fun game), I feel there has been a fundamental failure.If a game, in and of itself, is fun, microtransactions can enhance that. But the most crucial part where Marvel Puzzle Quest falls short is that the game so often isn't fun, with a frequently cheap AI, problematic scaling algorithm, and restrictions and level-locking everywhere you look.There are many characters to choose from, which is very appealing, and the art and animations are great for what they are. Unfortunately this also is a double-edged sword, since you'll unquestionably find yourself up against the old and familiar obstacle of never really getting characters you want -- and being unable to just buy the specific character you do, even with real money -- and instead getting no end of characters you really don't.I really wish Marvel Puzzle Quest had a more casual play option, but everything is geared to "encourage" you to spend real money on making the game a more fun experience, which it should have been from the start. I know it's a free game, but it would be a lot more enjoyable, and I think more people would be more willing to give it a better score and recommendation, if it were a game priced reasonably and given a limited cash shop, but crafted better and more enjoyably. It's just a plain fact that they couldn't find a way to monetize a more casual play option, so it's not there. As a result, playing the game often ends up a frustrating reminder that if you'd just pony up the cash, you could probably have more fun.Meanwhile, Juggernaut's getting his fist ready. Better bend over. Some of the characters are plainly broken outright, and Juggernaut? He's one of them. Not only does he have massive health, but all of his moves are devastating. And you guessed it: he will always -- always -- get the combos he needs.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												Typical puzzle game with a twist. Each super hero has special abilities that are charged up by matching gems of each color. For instance, a super hero may have a power that requires 12 "red" gems to charge, so you must match 4 sets of 3 red stones, then that power becomes available to use. There are some interesting strategic combinations that affect the outcome of the game, and the Marvel characters are beautifully rendered.It doesn't take long, however, before you doubtlessly realize that you have hopelessly screwed up your game, either by buying heroes when you should have been buying hero slots or leveling up your existing heroes. This will basically make the game a fun sucking grind early on. The obvious solution would be to start over from scratch. This is easy... if you are playing this game on a phone. If you are playing on a PC, you're basically screwed, because the developers haven't bothered to allow players to reset their progress on PC (at least not a way that's as easy as "start new game").Go ahead and look up how to reset the game, and you will find a lot of conflicting opinions, and very little that is likely to work, since the solutions are all from 2013. The quick and expensive way to make your game playable again is to buy tokens to fix your FUBAR game save... so, of course, that's where they want you to go... when phone users can just delete their file and start over from scratch.This game is hopelessly flawed on PC. It's literally stops being fun as soon as you hit the brick wall of battles the game says "are trivial" difficulty. Unfortunately, it's yet another underwhelming Marvel title on PC. Stick to the phone if you're going to play it at all.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												Marvel Puzzle Quest is effective at generating a false sense of achievement.  There are many different metrics by which you can make easy, regular progress.  Acquiring new characters, levelling them up, progressing through story missions, and reaching new reward tiers during the events all make it feel like your are gaining something.  Ultimately, though, it feels like a continuous grind with no real end goal.  Like many micro-transaction based games, it is more interesting to see how far you can progress without making a purchase than to buy either of their in-game currencies, so this may truely be a free-to-play game for you.

content:
Posted: January 13, 2014
												For the first couple of days I played this game I was a little frustrated.  It seemed that the items were very overpriced (and they are), and that I couldn't get anything I wanted.  However, If you are smart at how you spend your money, use your items, and which characters you play, you can do very well in this game with little or no cash.  The real game is in the PvP, which isn't PvP at all really.  The Prologue, is just that, a starting to the real game.  Once you get 3 characters around 25-30 you can actually start playing the game which is all in building various teams who's abilities compliment each other.  I started out with Iron Man Model 35, Storm Modern, and Black Widow Modern.  This team will take you very far.  Now the anchor of my team is Black Widow Original.  She can heal and steal AP so I almost always end a fight with full health.  She does very well with Wolverine or Thor.  As you can see I've spent many hours playing this game on my PC (although half or more was probably AFK time.)  I've spent $10 on this game and I've felt it was a good choice.  My husband also plays and he spent $5.  We both spent the money to buy hero coins which we used to open slots for more characters. You will need at least 12 to get started and I currently have 18. 18 slots is enough to keep my favorites.  I never felt the need or pressure to buy for anything else.A note on the PvP, you get to choose who you play.  If you don't like the team, press skip, and you will be presented with another choice.  You can find teams you can beat at any level and since the very dumb AI is controlling the opposing team you can generally beat teams much higher level with smart play.  You get either 70 or 140 ISO-8 for every match you win, and you should be winning nearly all of them since you get to choose who you fight.  With an average of 105 ISO-8  per match and matches lasting about 3 minutes  you can level up characters very quickly in RPG terms.  However it probably seems slow for a casual mobile app.  You get points in tournaments based on the ranking of the team you fight, not their level, so with smart picks and persistence you can rank well and get good rewards early on, but if you have to come in first, you're going to have to work hard and wait a long time.  In addition to the end of tournament rewards, there are frequently progression rewards which you get regardless of your final ranking.  As there are frequently multiple tournaments hapening simultaneously and shield trainer always available, even after you've exhauseted the story line rewards there is always plenty to do and more characters to collect.  I find Marvel Puzzle Quest fun and surprisingly addictive, yet not at all pay to win.  In fact, the items are so expensive that several hundred dollars wouldn't get you very far. So those who do spend mony don't have any real advantage beyond saving a few minutes.  In summary, if you can get over the slow grind to level 30, this game really takes off and becomes much more fun.  Don't spend hero coins or money on anything other than opening up more roster slots until you fully understand what you are getting in return (i.e. hardly anthing). Participate in the tournaments early and often as this is where the ISO-8 you need to level your characters comes from even if you don't place well.  I'm not surprised that the people who only played an hour don't like it, though.  It's not really a play for a few minutes kinda game.  It's much better suited to long sessions on the PC.  It's the most fun I've had for $10 in a while.

content:
Posted: February 4, 2014
												Interesting twist on bejeweledThe game play was mostly intuitive, although how exactly the enemies move/fight back is not very obvious, as there are different types of enemies that use different game mechanics to fight you. Also, choosing which ally is in front isn't very obvious either, even tho it's critical sometimes to know exactly who's in the front line and who will get the hit.This game, being free to play, has a leveling system that requires coins, which you can buy in the in-game store or otherwise purchase with real money. I'm not a big fan of free to play games for this reason, so it took away from my enjoyment of the game.The art and animations are pretty good, and the "storyline" is ok for a Marvel storyline. It's mostly just a big excuse to put all the Marvel characters together, but it does enough to provide a background for the game.Only not recommending this game because I dislike free to play. However, it is a solid bejeweled spin-off other than that.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19, 2016
												It's a match-3 puzzle game that lets you bring your choice of characters, each with their own special abilities, into the match. Depending on the characters, rules will be altered or added to that will alter how the match plays and can have a massive effect on the outcome of matches.Damage suffered is per-hero. Damage carries over between matches, so you can barely win one match and start another only to lose after your first turn if you don't wait for any suffered damage to your heroes to be restored. You can pay real world currency to hurry the healing along, but there's no requirement to do so.The publisher makes money from a cash shop, selling healing items, hero roster space, and random hero draws. You can get more heroes and ingame shop currency from playing the game, but even paying players feel an inventory squeeze if they're even slightly packrat-like.Think Puzzle Quest with a mostly optional microtransaction business model.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2014
												I read most of the reviews, and saw how negative people were because of the microtransactions. Having tried the game, I can say that even though there is a lot of microtransactions, they do not restrict you in any way. So far, I have been able to get most things just by playing, and have been awarded a decent amount of coins just because of playing. Of course, you won't be able to own everything by playing, but you also don't have to buy anything.As far as gameplay goes, the game offers a fine experience, some strategy, and a lot of puzzling, and I find myself enjoying it, especially considering that it's free.The best thing I can say is that you try the game yourself and see if you think that microtransactions bother you or not. In my opinion, I think they are not and that you can enjoy this game decently without paying anything.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2014
												I am not the biggest fan of freemium games since most requrie that you spend money to progress through the game. I wouldn't say that this one is the exception to the rule, but you can certainly enjoy the basics of the game without having to pay money to continue playing. I put in around 30 hours before I decided to pay 9.99 to add some ways to preserve some characters that I started winning. If you're willing to grind or play smart then you can certainly put the time in without spending a dime. I highly recommend playing the multiplayer section in the Danger Room to add some quality upgrades in a relatively easy manner. A couple quick cons - the newest update added a penalty for skipping hard multiplayer battles. It's not a huge penalty, but if you're in management or free mode then it's going to take a bite out of upgrading. I'd also like to see some of the prices come down a bit to make it easier to save your rewards if you don't want to spend money. Otherwise, this can be something to enjoy between FFVII or Metro:Last Light games.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												There's a pretty severe proviso on this game.You may need to spend a smidge money. Not to buy cards, but to buy card slots. You can win a lot of the in-game currency, and once your decks are strong enough you can get more. Events allow you access to even more, but if you don't have enough slots you can't capitalise on the randomness of the card drops. They've set a week's lifetime on any card drop before it decays, so if you're willing to lose cards while you farm the currency then don't spend a cent.It's not a bad game by any means, but it takes a lot to get off the ground and start winning successively and consecutively. If you're a bit timerich and waiting on some new releases not the worst thing you could play. But don't spend more than $20 on it.

												Addictive, free to play, jewel matching. Hero powers and damage variation of colors help add an element of stratgey to the board play. The RPG elements of collecting heroes, leveling them, and building the best team combination are the driving motivation. The story and delivery are nothing great, but what are you really expecting from this type of gameplay? The down time (hero recovery) period can be frustrating sometimes, especially when just starting. There are always events and tournaments happening that are enjoyable and can provide great rewards. Overall, this game is a great pass time and does NOT require any real money to advance (as so many reviews claim), have spent $0 and havent had any issues. 8/10

content:

												I read up on a lot of reviews before playing this and they heavily recommended against the free to play game because of the Pay-To-Win methods. Microtransactions are present and I can see where they're all coming from however this game is still a good game.For being free it provides the basic advantage of being there for you to play if you've got nothing better to do. The game isn't really one where you can sit and spend hours upon hours playing but it is great for a few minutes between things if you need to burn the time. For example, I play league of legends with my friends and always find the wait between matches about 5-10 minutes long with champion select and the loading screen included. Therefore I can get a few matches of Marvel in and still enjoy the game for what it is.After playing this game for almost a month I can finally see some serious problems as to why people wouldn't want to play this game. Even after a months time I'm unable to really collect higher level characters due to their rarity and the slow process of collecting coins to buy roster points. The game heavily presses for the purchase of coins however they're so damn expensive it would have been better for me to just buy the damn game for $60 to unlock everything. Which to be honest wouldn't even get you everything in this game since everything is given to you by chance.Either way after this month of playing I've still found myself getting one for a few matches and putting it away. Having fun and still progressing through the game even if it is slow. I recommend everyone to pick it up as a game to have on the side but it is definitially not a game I would spend all day playing.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												This ain't your Candy Crush Saga...Like any of the other Puzzle Quest games, this is a match 3 score puzzle game with the theme of Marvel Heroes. It has a story mode competeting off against the AI in various story scenarios, now with weekly special events allowing players a variety of PvE puzzle games to choose from. And there is also PvP arena, while also simulated by the AI, you'll face off against other player's team, composed of three of their heroes and/or villians. Competeting in these events (PvE and PvP) will place you upon a ranking system in brackets of other players around the world. In these brackets, there are milestones providing various bonuses as incentives to duel creating an addictive puzzle grind for glorious rewards.Generating in-game currency named, "ISO" you'll use this to level up your heroes and villians once you've unlocked (recruited) them either by purchasing the booster cards or earning them from playing the game. It's quite exciting earning cards, as each time you'll have a random chance - while some higher %'s than others - of obtaining that elusive hero or villian you've been after.It's a fantastic Puzzle Quest game, and I am a fan of the previous PQ games as well... so perhaps I'm biased, but it's definitely a fantastic match 3 puzzle game and highly reccommended by me.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												Addicting.  Having played Puzzle Quest on my PS3 I was familiear with the RPG/Match 3 hybrid mechanic.  If not, you soon will be, because the game is free, so there is no excuse to not try it out.  That being said, I'm sure the largest criticism will be that it is pay to win, which is not  *entirely* true.  If you play daily, participate in tournaments, join an alliance that is active and stay active....you will naturally earn gold coins (premium currency) and the ISO that is required for leveling characters.  You will end up selling premium covers (2 stars +), because roster slots cost gold coins, and you don't want to pay.  However, if you stick it out, keep playing, you will get those slots and then you just have to pray for good drops from cover pulls.The top players clearly pay or they have more hours in the day than God to play.  The game is meant to be casual, but can be cutthroat, give it a try, its the perfect game when you only have 15 minutes here and there.EDIT 9/10/14So being a player with 33 roster slots, Ive had some more time to reflect.  Clearly, as you progress without spending money, you are easily trumped in most high level encounters in tournaments, but success is not impossible with a little strategy and luck.  Most notably, I've noticed that as the developers continue to add new characters (covers or powers) to the possible roster, the chances that you will draw the same 3 star character necessary to level the one you already have becomes lower and lower.  For example, I've had a level 69 Hulk forever, because I have not drawn another cover due to the low 1% chance in most instances.  In the meantime I've accrued 5 or 6 other three star characters that are basically useless with only one cover outside of special circumstances during rare tournament opportunities.What this means simply is, if you can't afford new roster space to increase room for new characters, you will almost never level those three star characters necessary for higher level challenges.  The devs clearly use this to milk more money and stiff the consumer.  They need to add more two star characters and make three star character opporunities more plentiful.I still play, but with little opporunity for progression at this point, it is getting tedious and boring to play.

content:
Posted: February 4, 2014
												Interesting twist on bejeweledThe game play was mostly intuitive, although how exactly the enemies move/fight back is not very obvious, as there are different types of enemies that use different game mechanics to fight you. Also, choosing which ally is in front isn't very obvious either, even tho it's critical sometimes to know exactly who's in the front line and who will get the hit.This game, being free to play, has a leveling system that requires coins, which you can buy in the in-game store or otherwise purchase with real money. I'm not a big fan of free to play games for this reason, so it took away from my enjoyment of the game.The art and animations are pretty good, and the "storyline" is ok for a Marvel storyline. It's mostly just a big excuse to put all the Marvel characters together, but it does enough to provide a background for the game.Only not recommending this game because I dislike free to play. However, it is a solid bejeweled spin-off other than that.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												if you've ever played puzzle quest (1,2, kindgoms or galactrix, idk if there are others) then you'll find the gameplay similar (swap stones to match 3 vertically/horizontaly to cause damage to opponent & gain resources used to employ secondary abilities). this iteration of the series strongly borrows from free-to-play mmos/facebook games in the form of microtransactions. characters are upgraded through cards purchased through in-game currency which is gained through rewards for completeting missions or events, or bought through the in-game shop. it also suppliments the typical puzzle quest battle system with a 3v3 marvel vs capcom style team fight, which adds another level of complexity to the game.disregarding the whole play-to-win aspect, the game itself is fun, with great artwork and an interesting variety of iconic marvel characters. at times i find the pace a bit sluggish for a casual game, and the difficulty can sometimes spike unexpectedly, but overall it is a very fun game, without needing a huge investment of time to be fun.

This is a MARVEL to me and it broke the monotony from my much tamer and more usual game play.
