content:
Posted: September 2, 2015
												I neither recommend or dislike this game for a simple reason, and that is that you CAN get a lot of it without paying. What you cannot do is compete at the higher levels without paying or expand your character space.There are issues with the gameplay, it does seem rather annoying that whatever you do as a player the AI always get the jewels they want. And it is also very, very frusrtating that when you are fighting bosses who need certain colours for thier attacks they miraculously drop for them regularly but not for you, and the only way to beat them is to grind and compete in daily events to potentially win better characters.And therein lies the nub of this game, to use better characters and not scrap the ones you have invested time and ISO in you have to purchase character slots and these go up in price aswell as size as you play daily. So now I need 300 gold to purchase 3 slots, rather than being able to buy 1 for 100.This is all very clever from a P2W point of view, but will simply mean I will move on if I cannot win enough gold to use these characters. But the very, very sad part of that is that the characters have a time limit on their availability, tempting you to spend money. I find that rather manipulative and poor.I have seen players with six pages of characters, and goodness knows how much they have spent. That more than outweighs those of us who play for fun, so let them do it and enjoy a simple game for nothing.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
												What could be a fun puzzle game ruined by the same cash schemes and artificial time gates of many IOS ports.Between the forced real time recovery of any hero when  they take any damage, to clear grind or pay to win keep buying covers to power up heros aspect, any fun the game has is eroded by it's petty restriciton mechanics. the game makes the more frustrating aspects of puzzle quests even more frustrating because one bad match can make an entire day effectively moot.Worse still is that while stages have multiple rewards to earn, The game will more often than not randomly decide to reward you the item you already earned, and since you cannot re earn said reward you will be given the same pitance you'd get from replaying a stage fully cleared. i've had strings of six+ fights consecutively where the reward I was given was the only one i 'earned' every single time.Without the terrible healing restriction and a way to level up heroes outside of using the same currency you must earn to buy covers the game would be a fun, if inferior sueprhero version of the classic Puzzle Quest. As it currently is the game is just going out of it's way to force you to give them money, instead of making a product you want to pay for.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												Marvel Puzzle Quest is meant to be a puzzle game with RPG-ish elements where you can level up your character and increase the damage of their attacks by spending points on them. The thing is that you rarely get these points (coins in-game). You can tell that this game is the typical free-to-play game when they hit you with the fact that you either have to waste health packs on your heroes to recharge their health or wait 10 minutes to heal your heroes. Marvel Puzzle Quest is really designed as the average mobile game where you come back after your characters are able to be used (i.e. Injustice Mobile). So this is a Marvel version of puzzle quest, which is basically bejeweled except your actions control characters' attacks. There is a cool factor to this where you can increase the powers of your heroes by using resources you collect (Iso-8 Crystals) BUT you can't even purchase these upgrades until you purchase another "layer" of your character... AND THE THING IS that you can't do that without COINS, YES RARE♥♥♥♥♥COINS!!! Level 1 upgrades are 125 coins and I just want to point out that 200 coins costs 2 DOLLARS!!! Why do the creators try to screw us like this? But besides this In-Game-Purchase BS, the story really isn't even interesting, and the dialogue is quite boring. If only the heroes and villains had voices behind them it would be more interesting. This game does have some pros to it buy mostly cons. Not recommended...maybe to puzzle quest fans and very patient people but it doesn't change the fact that this game has tedious recharge times, boring dialogue and an uninteresting story.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												There's a pretty severe proviso on this game.You may need to spend a smidge money. Not to buy cards, but to buy card slots. You can win a lot of the in-game currency, and once your decks are strong enough you can get more. Events allow you access to even more, but if you don't have enough slots you can't capitalise on the randomness of the card drops. They've set a week's lifetime on any card drop before it decays, so if you're willing to lose cards while you farm the currency then don't spend a cent.It's not a bad game by any means, but it takes a lot to get off the ground and start winning successively and consecutively. If you're a bit timerich and waiting on some new releases not the worst thing you could play. But don't spend more than $20 on it.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												Addictive, free to play, jewel matching. Hero powers and damage variation of colors help add an element of stratgey to the board play. The RPG elements of collecting heroes, leveling them, and building the best team combination are the driving motivation. The story and delivery are nothing great, but what are you really expecting from this type of gameplay? The down time (hero recovery) period can be frustrating sometimes, especially when just starting. There are always events and tournaments happening that are enjoyable and can provide great rewards. Overall, this game is a great pass time and does NOT require any real money to advance (as so many reviews claim), have spent $0 and havent had any issues. 8/10

content:
Posted: January 28, 2014
												Although it incorporates many of the mechanics from its namesake, and art/characters from its theme, the game seems to lack depth and character development, instead relying on grinding or payment for character progression. The character artwork looks nice in combat as well as cutscenes, and the party system with character based skills is interesting with a good amount of variety, using the puzzle quest style of gameplay. This is overshadowed by the unfortunate fact that you will most likely not get access to all of the character skills and upgrades without grinding or paying for 'hero tokens', or hoping that an upcoming event has a chance to win an upgrade for your preferred character. As the difficulty increases you may need to ditch interesting low level characters for random high level ones just to keep up with the stat scaling.With better RPG and leveling elements I could recommend it, otherwise it feels like a chore to upgrade the characters you enjoy.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												Marvel Puzzle Quest is meant to be a puzzle game with RPG-ish elements where you can level up your character and increase the damage of their attacks by spending points on them. The thing is that you rarely get these points (coins in-game). You can tell that this game is the typical free-to-play game when they hit you with the fact that you either have to waste health packs on your heroes to recharge their health or wait 10 minutes to heal your heroes. Marvel Puzzle Quest is really designed as the average mobile game where you come back after your characters are able to be used (i.e. Injustice Mobile). So this is a Marvel version of puzzle quest, which is basically bejeweled except your actions control characters' attacks. There is a cool factor to this where you can increase the powers of your heroes by using resources you collect (Iso-8 Crystals) BUT you can't even purchase these upgrades until you purchase another "layer" of your character... AND THE THING IS that you can't do that without COINS, YES RARE♥♥♥♥♥COINS!!! Level 1 upgrades are 125 coins and I just want to point out that 200 coins costs 2 DOLLARS!!! Why do the creators try to screw us like this? But besides this In-Game-Purchase BS, the story really isn't even interesting, and the dialogue is quite boring. If only the heroes and villains had voices behind them it would be more interesting. This game does have some pros to it buy mostly cons. Not recommended...maybe to puzzle quest fans and very patient people but it doesn't change the fact that this game has tedious recharge times, boring dialogue and an uninteresting story.

content:
Posted: September 2, 2015
												I neither recommend or dislike this game for a simple reason, and that is that you CAN get a lot of it without paying. What you cannot do is compete at the higher levels without paying or expand your character space.There are issues with the gameplay, it does seem rather annoying that whatever you do as a player the AI always get the jewels they want. And it is also very, very frusrtating that when you are fighting bosses who need certain colours for thier attacks they miraculously drop for them regularly but not for you, and the only way to beat them is to grind and compete in daily events to potentially win better characters.And therein lies the nub of this game, to use better characters and not scrap the ones you have invested time and ISO in you have to purchase character slots and these go up in price aswell as size as you play daily. So now I need 300 gold to purchase 3 slots, rather than being able to buy 1 for 100.This is all very clever from a P2W point of view, but will simply mean I will move on if I cannot win enough gold to use these characters. But the very, very sad part of that is that the characters have a time limit on their availability, tempting you to spend money. I find that rather manipulative and poor.I have seen players with six pages of characters, and goodness knows how much they have spent. That more than outweighs those of us who play for fun, so let them do it and enjoy a simple game for nothing.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												Marvel Puzzle Quest is effective at generating a false sense of achievement.  There are many different metrics by which you can make easy, regular progress.  Acquiring new characters, levelling them up, progressing through story missions, and reaching new reward tiers during the events all make it feel like your are gaining something.  Ultimately, though, it feels like a continuous grind with no real end goal.  Like many micro-transaction based games, it is more interesting to see how far you can progress without making a purchase than to buy either of their in-game currencies, so this may truely be a free-to-play game for you.

content:
Posted: April 12
												Having played the mobile version of Marvel Puzzle Quest for a couple of years now, i decided to give the steam version a go. Unfortunately, an account cannot be shared across both platforms which is a huge shame. With that in mind, i find the mobile version better suits the game than on steam. Being able to play a few matches while on a train or waiting for something/someone is where the game excels, and it doesn't really work as well when sitting down for dedicated play sessions. If you are thinking of trying this game, i would suggest checking it out on mobile, as i've now decided to return to. There aren't many differences between the mobile and desktop versions besides some UI differences, and my recommendation for the mobile version is simply due to the easier ability to drop in and out of the game rather than any issues that i've encountered while playing the version available on steam.As far as the game itself goes, i do think it's one of the best games on the mobile market, and i've put hundreds of hours into it (possibly thousands, all things considered) There are over 100 recruitable characters (although it's worth mentioning quite a few are varients of the same characters) and the gameplay is quick to learn but can become very challenging and tactical as you rank up and face tougher matches. The game does point you towards in-game transactions a lot, as you would expect for a free game, but i personally haven't spent a penny in-game and have a very strong and competitive roster that i've managed to collect and level. There is nothing that is innaccessible without payment, and with events that constantly run and cycle every couple of days it always manages to feel worth my time. This isn't a game that you can lose yourself in and play for 6 or 7 hours on end, but it is a great game to play for short bursts or breaks and i would definitely recommend it to any fans of the marvel universe.

number of helpful: 8 of 18 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												I've been playing this game on my android since it was released, I've easily put 50 hours into the game, I have 25 roster slots, over ten heroes that are Lv30+ all without spending a dollar. Don't put this game down for microtransactions since you don't need to spend a dollar with all the rewards the tournametns and the PvE gives you.-Update-I still see people are complaining about the Microtransactions. 1) If you play the game daily roughly 2 hours a day and do all the missions in the PVE events and PVP a couple times a day you should get roughly 3,000-5,000 Iso-8, the tool to level up your characters. It costs roughly 20k Iso-8 to max out any 1* Hero and roughly 80k to max out a 2* hero. You will be able to max out any 1* or 2* character within weeks of just playing a couple hours a day. 2. You will also roughly get a few hundred Hero Points in the process, if you are starting out the game. Use them on the 100 Daily Deal Heroic pack. That is how you max out your 2*s. If you have played the game for a while, save the Hero Points for Alliance slots, or join an open alliance. I created a 20 person alliance and only spent twenty bucks on it, I could have waited a month for the same ammount of Hero Points. ((Some people spent a hundred))3. Now for the 3* covers, playing a lot in any tournament or event will nail you 1-3 3* covers of one hero. You will also get covers through the Heroic Packs and any other special pack that you spend your free hero points on. They require alot of Iso-8 to max out. 170k for a rough estimate. HOWEVER the final level still requires only 2500 iso-8, which is something you can easily get within an hour. 4. Guys this isn't a game that you get Lv100 of all the strongest characters within hours of playing. This game is set up more of an MMO where you have to do the slow grind to get to that point. I don't mind it. I currently have 5 maxed out 2* Characters at Lv85, 3 maxed out 1* characters and I have a handful of other 2 and 3* characters over lv50 with two that I just need to grind all the way to max level. I've only spent fifty bucks on this game because I actually felt like it. I didn't feel like I needed to in order to continue this game. To compare with other games I've played, I put almost a thousand bucks in to League of Legends and I had put six hundred bucks into Dungeon Fighter Online before that got shut down. I probably could spend more money into this game, but I don't.

You do not need to invest money in this game, you just have to have a good strategy. Here is hint: Take every event and go as far as you can in them. You will get nice rewards from events. Also, I am pretty excited when I get a new hero with good level or when I level up my favorites. I hope they will put Steam trading cards.In conclusion, it is a very nice game. It is casual, but you still need a little strategy. With my hint from above you may get far.

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												8/10This is a free-to-play Match 3 game.There are MANY others like it, but I'm a comic book fan, (Slightly more a DC/Vertigo fan but still love some of the Marvel lines.) and this isn't the worst thing to happen to the franchise, or even the top 3 terrible things. *If they got Halle Berry to VO the game, it could get there...)The game itself is adequately executed (as the producers of "Electra" should be...) It's ... well, it's Puzzle Quest, with a few Marvel bits thrown in so your power-ups share the names of your chosen heroes' powers (Iron man's Repulsors, etc)The "Story" arouond the game... They try, and didn't destroy a load of canon to beat a storyline around the missions.The Free-To-Play bit...Obviously they're going to try to take your money, but they don't throw it in your face constantly, nor do they ask you to "Share your victory with a friend" every 5 minutes. If you play a little bit every day you can easily get enough rewards to make up for not paying for stuff, but if you want you can speed up your success. Just remember to save all your "Hero Points" for when you actually need them, and you'll have them when you do come upon a need.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 3, 2014
												Under normal circumstances, I would say for a free to play like this its not bad. But there is one simple thing that drives me crazy, and that's the fact that you almost never get the covers you're looking for and that enemies get much stronger much faster than you can by simply grinding. I also have had issues where I will make a match, and that'll be it. Then the AI will make a match which leads to a chain of new pieces dropping and making more matches which goes on and on in a chain that I can never seem to match. This is annoying. I am not sure if it's my bad luck or if it's just the way the game is. Either way, the only people that really seem to do well are people who have no life and log mad hours into this game, or the people that don't mind dropping cash into the game in order to get the packs which in my opinion defeats the entire purpose of "free-to-play". In short, while many may enjoy this game and do well in it, I am not one of those people and cannot bring myself to recommend this game no matter how much I wanted to like it.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
												First off, it is free. I personally have not paid one dime to the devs. And I have a full roster of rare, legendary, and gold characters. If you choose not to pay as I chose NOT to pay, then you must have patience. I only played when I wanted. I didn't get obssessed with the events. I simply played casually. And it all fell into place. I started with Ironman, Black Widow, and Juggernaut. Kept winning with that combination and started collecting several other characters. My favorite line up right now is Thor, Black Widow (rare), and Juggernaut (or Storm..again, rare one). If you have patience and are not going to get swept up in having to win every event, not have to win every cover, not force yourself to play 3 or 4 hours a day then this game will be fine for you. The game concept is simple: match tiles/blocks to destroy segments but with the Puzzle Quest twist of having special powers to activate once you collect certain colored tiles (AP). I can confidently recommend this game. But you have to know what kind of player you are. If you need instant gratification and know you'll get♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥if you can't unlock all covers quickly or win every single event to get more covers, then don't play this game. If you feel you will reach into your pocket and throw all your money at this game to get a pay to win advantage and that is what is going to♥♥♥♥♥♥you off, then don't play this game. But if you can enjoy the game casually it can be very rewarding. And hey if you DO want to throw your money at it, then go ahead. Either way the game actually is fun. I just have to tell myself not to get wrapped up in the treasures that always seem to be outside my grasp. I kept my money in my pocket and played casually (10 hours a week or less). And when I figured that out, treasures started falling in my lap.

content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												Highly AddictiveCasual game. Some sort of a blend of a card fighting game and a three-in-a-row game, with some twists.Three of your heroes against one or more villains.Your heroes have some powers that can be used, after they have collected some pieces of a certain color.But, villains also have their own powers.That makes more interesting the three-in-a-row game, because the goal is to defeat the villains, trying to use your powers and, trying to avoid villains to use their ones.So, strategy is important.While fighting, you can get some cristals, which you can use to train your heroes (level up them).The bad side of this game is that your heroes go injured or dead and, there is a long waiting time until the health is being restablized, so you can end without being able to continue the game, until, maybe one day later.And, there is where this FREE to play game wants you. If you are anxious, you can buy game coins (with real money) to buy medkits, cristals, enhancements or whatever you need to restore health and to train your heroes.If you are ok being forced to leave the game until next day then, enjoy this game as it is.Dialogues are forgettable (I bypass all them) and, are badly translated to Spanish. They add nothing to the game, IMHO.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												I've played this for a while now.  While it IS fun, there are a lot of issues with it.  You can earn better heroes, but most of them will be rare and cost you a lot of money.  What's more, you'll have to get these rares repeatedly in order for them to be worth anything...on top of the hours upon hours of getting 20 crystals per fight in order to purchase a random character at 500...or the hundreds you spend leveling a character up...not counting the hours you have to wait for your characters to "heal".  This is NOT a game meant for a PC...instead it looks like a straight port from a tablet or iPad, and they're just trying to make more money off of it.  Great concept, but poorly executed.  Try a different match-3 game.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												I have only just started playing this game, but I disagree with the other reviewers right now...I think "Marvel Puzzle Quest: Dark Reign" is alot of fun, I know there are a ton of optional micro transactions that you can take advantage of (operative word being OPTIONAL), and I can see where this could become a "Pay to win" scenario on all fronts if you want it to be.  Brass Tax this is a fun game, if you keep your head where it belongs (between your shoulders not in your backside), and your pride out of the equation and just have fun... If you go into this game and you are a person with a pride problem who gets his feelings hurt and throw tantrums everytime you lose, knowing this is a potential "Pay to Win" environment with no money to make yourself cpompetitive then that is your fault, not a flaw in game design nor concept.The storyline is humorous and moves swiftly from battle to battle, the transitions and animations are top notch so far, and the over all design makes me want to play all  the time and start collecting comics again.From what I have seen, having so far finished the first story and half of the second... You DO NOT have to pay for, nor buy anything to have a good time. Tip: If you run out of heals and you have to wait for your heroes to regen health or revive, go make a sandwich, or grab a drink, and when you finish you will be ready to play again. (You don't just have to buy a health kit right then and there... if you do that is your fault not a flaw in the game... Personally I go play the android version of the game on my phone while I wait for the heroes on my desktop to recover, that way I can play as long as I want to with no real interruptions .-Peace-

												____MARVEL PUZZLE QUEST REVIEW____Upon logging into steam and finding this featured in the store as F2P, A part of me leapt in excitement. As a long term puzzle quest lover I found myself drawn into the universe that is Marvel Puzzle Quest. Instead of having one character, you have up to 3 that switch in mid battle (each character is strongest with a particular tileset). As you match tiles, you gain the amount destroyed as power which you can then use as abilities. This opened up some room for strategy, in which I would try to think 2-3 steps ahead and plan my attacks according to my characters strengths. The campaign is somewhat lackluster in the script department, with the cutscenes just being the same portraits as the ingame characters. However as you progress through the prologue, you are faced with goons that deploy timed tiles that explode after the timer expires. In certain situations you can be unlucky and not have any tiles nearby, but with careful planning, most tiles can be destroyed before their time expires. Going further into the campaign, these encounters just repeated, with very little varience. However, there is plenty of varience in the somewhat multiplayer aspect of the game. Instead of fighting other players in realtime, the opponent's party is controlled by the AI, which is rather predictable (always uses abilites when they get appropriate power), but because you are fighting someone else's roster, you think about what strategy they were thinking about with their particular roster. This is somewhat compelling, but the real fun comes in the weekly events. Every week there is a particular event in which you compete with up to 1000 players for a chance to win rare covers. This brings me to my next point: the levelling system.Instead of levelling like a normal rpg through experience points, you level by collecting the same cover with that particular ability and since heroes are level capped by the amount of covers they have, the more covers you have for a particular character, the higher you can level that character.This hampers progression and you will find that you will level the characters with the most covers instead of thinking about some strategy.  This is where the transactions come into play. There are two types of currency: Iso-8, which is very common and can be generated by winning each game and awarded by winning particular events for the first time; and Hero points, which can be found in only a handful of stages in the PvE campaign. Conversely you can place in the top 25 in events and earn hero points, but to be able to do this, you need a good hero roster, which in turn requires hero points. Therefore every player will either have to wait 1 week for 50 hero points (hero points are awarded for logging in once per week) or they can choose to pay $1 for 100. At first this doesnt seem like a big issue. only $1 and you can have 100 hero points. However, the more roster slots you have, the more hero points it costs to upgrade. This is one area where the developers aimed their micro transactions at. I am guilty of spending $5 for 600 hero points to unlock a few more slots. I am currently up to 20 slots and have only paid $5 which I believe is reasonable. The other area where microtransactions seem tempting is the recovery time for your heroes.As you battle, your heroes will get damaged. They will recover when they are not in use, but as you gain higher levels, the characters take longer to recover. For example, a level 1 Iron Man takes only about 10 minutes to fully recover, as apposed to a level 50 Iron Man, which takes 4 hours to recover. The whole aspect of waiting for characters to recover interrupts the flow of the game, which seems like a good idea when you're on the move/on a mobile device. However, this should have been removed with the PC version as most people can just play a few rounds, then they have to wait 2-3 hours to recover. You can instantly recover by using medkits which are somewhat rare, or can be purchased for 50 cents each. This price of 50 cents doesnt seem high, but when you have to do it almost every battle, you start to feel a pinch on your wallet.One strategy that I believe newbies should employ (and this is only to help progression and to enjoy the game as it should be: uninterrupted) is to set your system clock forward. This tricks the game into thinking that time has passed and your characters will recover the amount of time you put the clock forward. Ignore the events, just focus on the prologue, get through it and level up your characters. Once you have finished the campaign, set your clock back to normal time and use 1 medkit on each character.This "trick" should not have to be used and it's bad gameplay design to have to resort to such things. However, with all this said, I have put about 100 hours into this game over the last 2 weeks, so they must be doing something right. Think of this game as a CCG with puzzle quest elements. Overall I would recommened this because it is free and you can still get a lot of enjoyment for free.____Pros____+Classic match 3 with marvel heroes+Weekly events and login rewards+Randomised PvP battles keep it fresh____Cons____-Progression hampered by random levelling system-Cant battle steam friends in realtime-Unable to sync IOS version with steam-Predictable and repetitive AI

content:
Posted: December 17, 2013
												This game ramps up in difficulty immediately after getting you hooked, like a lot of bad free-to-play models. Based on the difficulty, I can't imagine it would be fun even if I paid them money. And I even got lucky and "found" a level 35 Wolverine when all of my other heroes were Level ~6. Even with that, so many of the missions are ridiculously hard. (Ones labeled as Trivial are medium-hard, and those rated as Normal are hard to impossible.I'd rather they just make a good game for a flat $4.99 (as a ported phone game, or else $19.99 for a "real" game) than make a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ game that I can make slightly less ♥♥♥♥♥♥ by giving them money via extortion.My advice is BUY AND PLAY PUZZLE QUEST 2. That game is amazing and makes this game looks like a preschool game. Optionally, you can play Puzzle Quest 1. It's good but slightly annoying in the way the campaign is laid out (TONS of random encounters). It's a fun game, but can't hold a candle to the perfection that is Puzzle Quest 2. The only problem with Puzzle Quest 2 is it's too easy, but that's okay, it's still fun. There's a difficulty setting, I'd recommend turning it up and if you can't beat a boss villain twice then turn it down. Otherwise most of the peon challenges are on the easy side. (Which is fine if you just want a casual time-waster.)

content:
Posted: December 14, 2013
												If you like the core Puzzle Quest gameplay, this is worth checking out. There's a lot of free gameplay here.  It's definitely designed around throwing money at it though.  It's a good variation on the classic Puzzle Quest formula. I like the art they used, and the variety of Marvel characters included.  I've played 8-9 hours of it so far and haven't spent a cent.  If they ever run a good sale on the Hero points and ISO 8 stuff, I'd be tempted to get some. The character health system reminds me of a Facebook game.  Like those games where you have a certain amount of "energy" or "turns" you can do before having to wait for it to recharge. Thankfully you seem to get 5 free health restoring packs every day, plus you can earn some as rewards for completing the missions in game. I like to play in relatively short spurts. Play a mission or two, then go do something else while my teams heal up. Overall it's not a bad "freemium" game. I'm not really sure where the limits of free play end though, or if there's a limit.

content:
Posted: March 10, 2015
												This game used to be a lot of fun. However, recent updates have changed the game engine. It has always been pay-to-win, but that's not my problem with it. The thing is, it gets you to compete in Vs. competitions for prizes. When you get high enough in the standings, The AI begins to manipulate the puzzle board so that the opposing team scores a multitude of extra turns, causing huge damage and amassing a lot of mana for the other team. So you die and you have to use health packs to resurrect your characters. Which means you have to buy health packs or pay for a shield.  I don't mind paying for character slots, or even a shield if I'm not going to be able to play for several hours. But it's ridiculous to ask me to pay even as I'm playing. Other game manufacturers try to get people to play their games, and these guys have a game that people want to play, and rather than capitalize on that, their strategy is just to nickle and dime you to death on health packs. Ridiculous. Unless they fix it, I would only recommend trying this game if you have a lot of self-hate, and don't mind forgetting how you spent your money.

Posted: September 26, 2014
												Highly AddictiveCasual game. Some sort of a blend of a card fighting game and a three-in-a-row game, with some twists.Three of your heroes against one or more villains.Your heroes have some powers that can be used, after they have collected some pieces of a certain color.But, villains also have their own powers.That makes more interesting the three-in-a-row game, because the goal is to defeat the villains, trying to use your powers and, trying to avoid villains to use their ones.So, strategy is important.While fighting, you can get some cristals, which you can use to train your heroes (level up them).The bad side of this game is that your heroes go injured or dead and, there is a long waiting time until the health is being restablized, so you can end without being able to continue the game, until, maybe one day later.And, there is where this FREE to play game wants you. If you are anxious, you can buy game coins (with real money) to buy medkits, cristals, enhancements or whatever you need to restore health and to train your heroes.If you are ok being forced to leave the game until next day then, enjoy this game as it is.Dialogues are forgettable (I bypass all them) and, are badly translated to Spanish. They add nothing to the game, IMHO.

content:
Posted: March 23, 2015
												Here's the problem.  If you get into this game, you will want to pay.  There is something about it that hooks into your hoarding instinct if you keep playing.   It is under constant development and the new characters keep it fresh.  That's worth paying something.I played this on my phone for six months and then decided to start playing on the PC so that I have a better (bigger) interface.My ground rules WERE:  No buying ISO-8 (experience points).  No paying for 10 packs or abilities.   Freely spend to buy slots when I win a new hero.   If you keep those rules, they payout is much like a subscription:   You win a couple of new characters every month and you pay a little to expand your roster.  Very reasonable.Then they introduce a rare character like Professor X.   He's really good (4-star).  If you buy a 42 pack which features him (3.2% chance per card draw of getting one of his three abilities) then there is about a 25% chance you don't get him in the draw of 42 cards.  ((1.0-0.032)^42)   What's the chance of getting all three abilities in a 42 pack?  Haven't done the math, but it must be around 5% or worse.So how much is a 42 pack?  15800 gold points.  You buy gold points for about 20000 for $100.   Therefore if you want a solid chance at getting all three abilities, you might pay about $400-$500.   You could get luckier.Knowing all this, I still bought a 42 pack this week and got two of the three abilities.   I was very lucky and I can barely resist buying another 42 pack.  That is the hook.Playing with the low level characters is very fun, there'se nothing wrong with it.  It's the desire and excitment about playing with a new one which makes you break your rules.BTW, the endpoint for cost of a slot for a character seems to be about 850 gold per slot.  That's about $4.25 per character once you have a fullish roster.   If you win a character, you pay $4.25 to keep it.  Fine.   But then you want the other 2 abilities that you didn't win.   Keep that under control and you will find this game reasonably priced.Oh, BTW, you do get all of the 1 and 2 star characters essentially for free over time and the cost of the extra slots is cheap at first.  It's the 3 and 4 stars that tempt you into paying.   You'll be happy in the moment and kind of sick in the long run.I saw a comment on a review which pointed out that any free to play game that you play for more than a couple of hours should have a massive thumbs-up.  OK, so thumbs up for that.  You'll love it for 5 or 10 hours, then you have to start resisting the temptation to pay.Having said all this, I can't argue with the thumbs-down reviews.  They're not bull####.  Watch your wallet if you start playing this, especially if you love it.

YouTube™ Video: Steam Cleaning - Marvel Puzzle Quest 

			Views: 36		

			We crack open my year old account to play some good old fashion match three with a marvel twist. The premise is straightforward, match color gems to earn energy to fuel your team's special attacks.		

The premise is straightforward, match color gems to earn energy to fuel your team's special attacks.  Four clears a row, while five grants an extra turn.Teams are built up of three unique characters that you invest currency into to increase their power.  It can be daunting at first to jump into a F2P game, there is always that flashing notification to encourage you to spend money.However, Marvel Puzzle Quest is balanced well that if you choose to spend time over money you will find a good amount of success.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 27, 2014
												Right so I've played this game for quite some time and it's a faily enjoyable timesink. I've been told it's like puzzle quest, only you have multiple people on your team so you can choose who to take hits from and there are more tactics to it.There is a pay-to-win strategy in that you can spend all your money to get tokens to buy powerful heroes (or villains) and have them on your team. The most powerful ones are the most expensive ones, obviously, with the biggest level cap. You can sell old cards you don't want as you have a limited roster of heroes to have and a limit of 3 in each battle.Beyond that, if you've played puzzle quest or any matching game you've got the idea of the game play to get at least 3 in a row, but here different characters deal different damage. For example, my group has Storm, Hawkeye and Iron Man. Iron Man deals the most damage with red so when they're matched he attacks and is open to attacks. Black ones Storm is most powerful at so she ends up in the firing line. they all have abilities based on colours you collect so there's also the tactic of wanting a really powerful ability to activate, but you can't use it unless you have X amount of this coloured jewel. For example, Iron Man's best power is Ultra Feron Beam which, at the moment, requires 19 Blue. 19 is a huge number, but with it he deals a huge amount of damage (which one-shots most villains by the time I get the amount) and even if it doesn't defeat them, it stuns them for 1 turn. Some abilities are direct attacks, stuns, destroys tiles, transforms tiles so depending on who's in your group, you can string together a large amount of abilities and combos to win the game.I only play this at a time sink for when I want to hear background commentary on a game or movie and it works well for that. Also every day if you win a combat you get given a special daily reward which can be anything from hero points (also attained in game) to hero cards. You also  will want to re-play many battles as there are alternate rewards where you can have the chance to win 1 out of 4 choices, but only a chance which forces a grind, but a enjoyable grind.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												This game is getting a lot of flak for having micro transactions, which is true it does have a number of boosts or tokens you can buy to cheese your way through the game, but that can all be pretty much ignored. Each hero you use has HP which can get hurt during a stage, heroes automatically heal themselves over time or you can use a medikit for a full heal which auto regenerates over time. This kind of mechanic can be seen in a lot of F2P games like Farmville or Travian. I had gotten though the first level/city/whatever without needing to spend a dime and in the second area boosts made an appearance which yes, you can buy, but you will also receive free boosts just by playing. The only thing that got on my nerve is each stage has 2-4 rewards for beating the level which are unique the first time you receive it, but then if you would receive that same reward you get a paltry 20 ISO (in game resource) so if you want a full clear you have to continually do the same stage over and over.

content:
Posted: May 1, 2016
												Marvel puzzle quest’s game mechanic is amazing. As a fun of puzzle quest, I got hook to this game early on. However, the pay-to-enjoy aspect kills it for me. The game encourages players to have a large roster of heroes in order to enjoy a specific mission for the week. In order to increase your roster, you need to gain a currency which is acquired through drops from prologue battles, finishing a mission with a high ranking score than other players or purchase it with real money. Obtaining a hero you want or levelling a hero you have also requires too much time and money. Gaining a 1 or 2 star hero is not a problem. Getting a 3 to 4 star though is a different story. You either have to be lucky at getting a 3 star hero from the standard cover drop, finish a mission with a high ranking score, or use gold to get draw a cover from the mission drop.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 1, 2014
												Having burned a lot of hours on this game, I would love to give it a positive review. The gameplay is decent and the character balance is fairly good so long as one learns how their skills synergize with each other. The plot is nothing special, but it's better than the atrocity Marvel sold to us as the Dark Reign crossover event. It dragged to hell and just wasn't very good.So why am I refusing to recommend it? No, it isn't because of Pay 2 Win. Yes, the game suffers from that severely; people willing to burn hundreds of dollars on this game will quickly find themselves way above other players, with most high-ranking players having obviously bought their way to victory via cover upgrades and hero packs. But in the end, there can still be a satisfaction of working your way up to that level and doing a good job with what you can earn for free.The problem is the AI, which has been horrendous ever since the original Puzzle Quest and hasn't been improved in the slightest. You see, the thing with Puzzle Quest games is that their grids are not generated on the fly. Rather, each column has gems pre-generated for a good 20 drops in advance. The AI knows that; it is given full information to which gems are going to drop next, meaning it can set up combos by abusing information the player has no way of accessing.The result is that if you play this game, you should get used to losing not because you did bad, but because the AI made one move which escalated into 10-30 successful combinations, overloaded its resource pool and allowed it to spam you to death in one move. There was a time when I legitmately sat there for 30 seconds, doing nothing but watching as gems drop onto the field and immediately successfuly match themselves because of one enemy move.I could forgive Pay 2 Win, but I will never forgive artificial difficulty achieved via a cheating AI. As such, I cannot possibly recommend this game to anyone.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2016
												Having played a ton of match-3 games I can safely say that Marvel Puzzle quest is one of the better options out there. Solid gameplay, frequently updated, tons of free stuff and new content roughly every 2-3 weeks. All of your favorite Marvel heroes in one game with many more to come. Unfortunately the game has become a bit of a grind fest with players having to sink in some 2-3 hours a day. I personally don't mind it but if you don't fancy playing for that long you might want to skip the game. My advice - give the game a go. Solid, fun , decent match-3 game on par with some of the other similar titles like Gems of War and Duelyst. Fan of the match-3 genre and superheroes? Give it a go, do it some justice and get hooked.

content:
Posted: December 16, 2013
												I can really recommend this Puzzle Quest in the Marvel universe.The adventures are plenty and fun, there are unique events every day so you won't get bored, and the tactics are nice and varied (big differences between fighting goons and fighting heroes). Since you play 3 characters with up to 3 powers each (and there are a lot of characters) you'll have plenty of choice and it's fun to maximize the efficiency of your team.It does have a rather peculiar monetization system (it's free-to-play), which I have read nothing but negative comments about, but I honestly do not mind it at all, which is really weird since typically I wouldn't touch game like this with a 5 feet pole.I watched TotalBiscuits WTF is.. of this game and so didn't expect much of it. Thought I'd deinstall in 5 mins. Instead I have been playing a lot. On and off while doing other stuff, just taking the time to let the heroes heal back up. Played this way, in between multitasking, I really like this game. I recommend you watch TotalBiscuits (or another) review though. The monetization system can put you off.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												TO clarify at the start, i am Recommending the Mobile version, NOT the PC version.I play this game pretty reguarly on mobile and the majority of complaints i see come from the timers for heroes to heal and microtransactions. The microtransactions were recently inflated to obscene prices on mobile as well but in all honesty you do not need them to enjoy the game, i advise spending Iso cyrstal on levelling your heros and after a couple of lighting rounds and other events you'll amass heroes faster than you can get space to hold them all. Im at 19 character spaces without paying for any 'fun' coinsAs for the Timers of health regen, It was originally designed as a mobile game/ gate mechanism to prevent you from playing the whole game endlessly. That obviously does not fit well here on PC, but i spend weeks playing this on the mobile to return each day to play a bit more until i get bored or all my main characters are awaiting regen.The game itself however is your typical Puzzle quest game! A match 3 gem game where any colours you match are stored for use as Powers that your characters have. The game ends when you reduce the enemy team to 0HP. I won't lie, sometimes you will feel cheated by the game for chaining colours and anniliating your team, but it happens sometimes for your benifit as well. Also some battles are so artifically hard thats about my only legitimate complaint about it. When you come up against a level 230 Venom as an optional mission, yeah you'll skip it but think how your even supposed to complete it as currently most chracters can only reach Lv 141.But to re-iterate, i really enjoy this game. Even the "PvP" aspects which are just more single player matches vs an AI using another players characters. The choice shouldn't be about wether to play it or not, it should be about what platform to play it on.  And i choose Mobile.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												I've played this game ALOT on my android phone, and just saw this released today on steam.  Thinking i could play my game on my PC without draining my phone battery all the time i quickly loaded it up.  The problem is....it doesn't access your activity from your phone.  It's a completely different server/database even though it's the *exact* same game.  Having grinded a ton on the phone version, i'm simply unwilling to put in the work to get back the same stuff i have now, and anyone else doing this on android will probably think the same thing.That said, the game is very fun once you grind through for a week or so and get an idea for what good character combinations are.  Fans of Puzzle Quest will be very pleased with the way it plays, though you'll find yourself skipping the dialog which is something i never did in puzzle quest.  Pick it up, and don't worry about spending money.  There's a very limited # of characters right now, and there's many ways to win them.  Only spend money if you want more variety of characters when you first start out, or if you're taking the tournaments seriously.  They're serious time sinks and more characters are required to grind out 2-6pt matches to get top 10.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												I originally recommended this game, but no longer do. The primary reason is that power creep makes it so that you can put in thousands of hours into the game, but still have a worse roster than someone who put in a fraction of that effort in the last 2-3 months. Unless you are willing to spend at least 6-8+ hours a day into a game like this, and at odd times, I don't recommend it. Original review below.===This is quite a decent puzzle quest (match-3) setup with the additional backdrop of the Marvel universe. The biggest difference between this and a typical puzzle quest is the addition of timer counters, which trigger effects for either side. There is also the addition of standard attack and hp for each character, based on the color matched. This triggering difference leaves you trying to balance the matching of strong attacks with trying to get rid of opponents stronger timed attacks. Strategy wise, often you have to allow certain timed attacks to go off. Some pvp enemies also do not make moves at all, but attack only with timer counters.Leveling is restricted by a character power level, based on the abilities of your hero and the level of those abilities, raised by an ingenious card system. These ability cards are won through missions, tournaments, and general pvp play. Of course the rarer character ability cards are hard to get and require many hours of investment.There are 2 main types of currency, Iso-8 or xp (the common currency) for leveling up characters, and Hero points (rare currency) for gaining additional hero spots. Any other use of Hero points is mostly a waste. Honestly, the monetization is a little ridiculous. Iso-8  is not worth buying at all unless you are a pay to achieve kind of person. There is a huge temptation to buy Hero Points when you just need a few more to recruit the next hero. Character balancing has been decent overall, though many characters are plain useless unless you manage to level them up, or they are temporarily 'iso' boosted for a tournament. Overall, this is a great time-waster and quite addictive. I can't count the number of times where I was like, just one more game before I go to bed, even after 100 instances like that had already passed. I really have to quit playing this game. After one more round.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 2, 2014
												GAMEPLAYBasic design is 3-vs-3 team of super heroes where each hero has 2-3 powers and they level up with XP. You do Bejeweled style color matches to build up the powers and activate the power which either affects the board to your favor (like forming defensive shields, invisibility for your character, bleed damage tiles, secret trap tiles, count-down timers that have some affect, and many other tile types that are essentially damage, buffs, debuffs, heals and so on). As time goes on and you win matches you gather both XP (called ISO-8) and character covers (new characters, new powers, or level-ups for existing powers). You build your character, you level them and have fun.MODESThere are two main Modes:1) Story - You play a storyline with a lot of different types of teams you fight and this is called the "PvE" side of things in the game.2) Versus - You play matches against the computer where they other people's teams are computer-controlled.Both modes very fun.MICROTRANSACTIONSMicrotransactions do speed up the game for you but are NOT required. You can start out easily and keep playing it and you will easily get good characters reasonably quickly. Alternately, spend $5 to $20 like a normal game and get your boost.PROsThe game is very well designed. There is a lot to do and the devs are constantly working to add more and fix the existing, Many fun events all week long. Great gameplay that is easy to pick up but the strategy is deep. All your favorite Marvel superheroes.It simply is a good addictive game. YMMVMicrotransactions help you speed things up.CONsCurrently the only downside is that the PC version and the Mobile version are kept completely separate so if you start on one you are stuck using that version as all your progress is limited to that version. This *needs* fixing but so far nothing. :/TLDRYou are doing your gamerself a disservice if you don't spend at least a few hours playing this game. :) It is excellent and strongly recommended.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
												I have to say I completely disagree with what the top reviews are for this game.First off let me say that it is FREE TO PLAY & not pay to win.The in game currencies that everyone is raving about are really given to you quite often. I would like to point out that you cant simply pay your way to the ultimate team of characters. Really it is quite smart in that you have to get "covers" that unlock your powers & let you level up from in game rewards. It can be frustrating as hell when you can't get the cover you need to level up but it also means you can just drop $30 on your hero (or villian) & perfect them. The other side of this is in my experience you are only matched with players who are of a similar skill level to you. You shouldn't be getting nerfed at anytime.I have only spent real world money on expanding the amount of heroes I can have & I didn't even need to do that, just wanted to have more people. I would say it cost me $8 bucks because I did it a couple of times. It's worth noting though that I was given plenty enough of the game gold for free, I just chose to spend it like an idiot on trying to get rare players!With that I would like to give out some hints that are really going to save you alot of time.#Use the in game gold that you get through playing to expand your roster first instead of trying to get rare characters. The more slots you have the more likely you can level up. Also means with mulitple characters you can play with one set while the other heals.#Pick two (maybe even 2) of the one star heroes at the start (Iron man, Black Widow, Storm, Juggernaught, Venom,) & focus on levelling them up. Cover drops are ultra common & a fully powered level 50 one star player is really powerful, you can beat much higher levels if you use skill. I have got other characters far past level 50 & still throw Storm in against high level players because here powers are so strong.#Play the daily events. Even if you only have ♥♥♥♥♥♥ characters you can at least get a cover drop from playing only 1 or 2 matches.#Don't forget when you are starting out that in the daily events you can skip a match if you think you will lose. There is a button in the lower left hand cornerAnyway, obviously I enjoy the game. It's a great time waster (as you can see by my hours) You can choose to trust me or you can choose to trust someone with .2 hours game time. Good luck!

												So yeah, it's another match-3 color game. I saw a lot of people say it is not as good as the original puzzle quest and yet it is a very fun and addicting game.Beyond the basic mechanic of lining 3 colors to progress you have many interesting features. First of all, you have to collect hero cards(which drop randomly after a game was won, or you can buy them). Before the start of each game you can select 3 heroes to play with. Each hero has skills, which can be activated if you accumulated enough gems of a certain color. The game is lacking in some social interaction options, but the developers update the game from time to time and balance heroes.In the end it's a very colorful and addicting game, and hey, who doesn't want to make their own superhero team.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												I really enjoy this game, and would recommend it to anyone who likes puzzle games. It is a free-to-play model, which may frustrate some, but I found it to be no problem, since the basic gameplay is solid enough to warrant a decent playthrough. Admittedly I have not played a lot in the PC version, since I started off with Android, but I find this game to have a decently attractive presentation.Graphics: The character designs are interesting, and the animation is decent, especially for a free to play puzzle game.Concept: This is basic puzzle quest, except there are up to three characters on each side per battle instead of one. The leveling system is a little odd, since leveling your characters requires ISO, but leveling their powers requires covers, which can be bought or won in game. Some covers are aggravatingly hard to get, but it shouldn't stop anyone from enjoying the game, because the lack of leveling one hero's powers does not break the overall experience.Sound: Overall, the sound design is good. I wouldn't say it was amazing, since the music is repetitive and generic and the sound effects accompanying each power can get old once a certain power is used multiple times in a battle. The sound won't win any awards in my book, but it is decent enough to not detract from the experience of playing this game.Replayability: This game is really replayable. The basic concept is solid, and the gameplay, although it relies a bit on luck, is addicting and engaging. Levels in the game can also be replayed for different rewards, which encourages another playthrough. In most games, backtracking is considered a chore, but in this one I find it to be worth while, since the main gameplay is fun, and it is not to tedious or necessary to complete further levels in the game. In other words, it is optional to those who are completionists, or who are looking for something in particular.Grade: 8/10 (Honestly, a number cannot truly describe an experience, but I am including it for reference and a quick glance to see the sum of the parts I have described.)I hope all find this helpful in determining if this is the right game for them.

												This game is very much like a Match 3 Collectible Card Game.  Basically through playing rounds and being ranked highly for an event you get in-game currency, and cards to either upgrade or add to your roster.  The characters each have skills which can be used after you destroy enough of that color gem.Each character I've seen so far has different attacks from the next one.Unfortunately this game has no actual interaction between players asside from an alliance system.[at this time]  It feels like a grind machine, but there are stories associated with a lot of the events. As far as the game goes I would recommend it for anybody that wants a simple game to play to waste time.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												The reviews for this game on Steam are generally negative, and that is unfair. This is a free to play game, that does feature strong incentives to spend on microtransactions, and that is, indeed, hatefull. I am the first to agree that something is very wrong in the industry right now regarding the f2p model. However, I believe a game should still be judged by how good a game it is in its own right. And this match 3 game is, in that regard, quite spectacular. The implementation of the original puzzle quest design is great, the look and feel of the game is pleasing and professional (it looks way better than puzzle quest 2, and better than most games of the genre), and there is a deep strategic level to the gameplay, which is quite surprising. Moreover, the use of the Marvel IP is clever. There is a pretty nice story going on, which is tied up with events on the comics, with the intentional cheesy but great dialogues that are a staple of the genre. Collecting your favorite heroes from Marvel universe is a fun activity in itself. There is a good variety of heroes, from both X-men and Avengers comics, alongside playable villains and rarer heroes (Punisher and Invisible Woman, for instance). Each hero play different, with obvious dps, tank and support roles, so that finding a team that works well together, and the right way to level them so they will interplay efficiently, is an interesting challenge. It delivers on all its promisses, being both a good Marvel game, and a good, a very good indeed, Puzzle game. It's microtransactions scheme is a big flaw, something I wish I would never encounter in any other game again. Unfortunately, that is where the industry is right now, and it is killing otherwise great games.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												Disclaimer:  Yes I have used the microtransactions and have invested money into this game, but I did so not out of a feeling of being underpowered to enjoy the game, but after nearly 60 hours of game time.Ok, that out of the way, I have to say that I really enjoy Marvel Puzzle Quest.  If you can just set aside the microtransaction part of the game, there is a lot of game here to enjoy.  Once you get to know the basics of the heal mechanics as well as learn the abilities of the characters in your stable, it becomes highly strategic and addictive.  You will want to get engrossed in the cycle of fighting through the "campaign" missions to earn recruitment drops in the hopes of upgrading your stable.  Once you have your "go-to" team, you'll take place in the daily challenges which are something like a-synchronous matches with other players where you earn points toward a reward.  The more points you accumulate through battling other teams, the higher up the ranking ladder you climb, but the higher you are, the more you are worth in points to those below you.  These "tournaments" can become highly addictive as you constantly battle and check your standing, and the instant feedback is pretty gratifying.  Its also pretty intimidating when you see other players that have level 100+ characters.  But I just placed 1st in a tournament with only level 40 or so characters, so it can be done without being ridiculously overpowered, hence the strategy.  The other cool thing is the variants of the powers and the characters, and a feel of wanting to collect them and get them leveled up.  This however is where my only complaint comes in.  Your roster size is limited by a slot system.  And you have to pay for slots using the in-game "hero points" currency.  Depending on how you play and how well you do in the events, you may come to a point that you have more waiting recruits, not enough slots, and not enough hero points to unlock new slots.  The game gives you 7 days before recruits you earned expire, and that may or may not be enough time to earn enough hero points to fix them in your squad.  It is the only "micro-trap" that I have seen really.All in all I have over 170+ hours on the game now, and I would gladly recommend it to anyone.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												Marvel + Puzzle Quest has got to be illegal.  The substance is so addictive, it's probably regulated by the government.Marvel Puzzle Quest is pretty much what it sounds like.  It's a Bejeweled-style game with Marvel Heroes.  You pick a 3-hero team and battle against a computer controlled team.  As you make matches, you gain "Action Points" to activate one of the abilities of heroes to do damage.  Whoever wipes the other team wins. There's a cash shop element, of course.  All cash-shop money can be earned in game.  Purple money is earned pretty regularly, and Gold money is earned by ranking in the tournaments.  You don't need to spend money to get anywhere in the game.  It just takes longer.The game is updated constantly.  New story events, new tournaments, and new rewards come in two or three times a week.  There's plenty to do.  I do recommend setting up a facebook account so you can gift/receive rewards that come in.  It speeds up leveling up your characters significantly.Overall, this game is a great time waster.  Give it a try.

content:
Posted: February 28, 2016
												I'm a mobile user, I kind of wished that I started here but the effects would still be the same. This is a P2W game all the way. I've been using the app for over a year and the only reason I haven't deleted it is because I've invested so much time in it. But I deleted The Quest For Stuff and that Simpsons one when they kept moving the goal posts further and further until you could only reach them if you paid for it. I'm going off track but it's kind of related.Everything about this game is severely P2W, the majority of updates ove the past year has been catered to "the elite" so they can stay in their position by paying for it. When I first started playing they were still introducing third tier characters, when they introduced fourth level characters they were available in standard character packs as I managed a neat couple of drops.Then things started changing, when fourth and fifth tiers started developing they dropped even fourth tier characters from standard packs. The drop level even for third tier dropped with standard packs and a legendary option was added, but to achieve this token you'd have to parcipate in PvP and PvE events with over the top achievements to get there. I work fourty hours a week, even devoting two hours in the morning before work, playing sporadically through my breaks and a couple of hours after work gets me nowhere, My points always end up halfway to where it's needed even with everything I put in. It seems like if I want to achieve anything in this game I need to quit my job and devote my entire life too it,The P2W goes even further with later updates, not only can you upgrade tiers 2/3/4/5, if the character is already maxed out you can make them chanpions then up their levels even more. I've been playing for over a year and this game is still finding ways to punish me and reward the people who throw money at it even more,Pro's\Con's:There's a variety of characters, just be prepared to pay for them.There's a variety of events, just be prepared to pay for them too,

content:
Posted: December 11, 2013
												I didn't think a 'Puzzle Quest Game' about Marvel could actually be any fun but it is. Those unfamiliar with Puzzle Quest; it's not about just mindlessly matching colors like in Bejeweled. If you don't either plan out your moves (based on your team/moveset) or prevent your enemy from planning theirs, you'll find yourself quite easily defeated.However.. with this game being both another Marvel game as well as being Free-2-Play it shouldn't come as a surprise that the game does have Pay-2-Win elements even though there is no real-time PvP. That said, I'm one of the very few people out there who would still recommend this game.There's still plenty of enjoyment you can get out of this game without paying by either treating it as a casual 'facebook game' or by just playing it really smart. The latter really goes a long way if you understand the mechanics and are able to master your playstyle/heroes.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2015
												This is my third review of the game. I've spent over 900 hours playing MPQ and for the most part I did enjoy most of my time on the game. I've gotten to know a decent amount of people and I've been in some of the best alliances the game had to offer on the pve side of things. I did do pvp sometimes but to me what MPQ isn't real pvp, it's simulated so I really wasn't into it.MPQ is a fun puzzle game but I can't recommend this game UNLESS you plan on putting in some serious cash or you don't care about being a top player or in a top alliance. Understand that you can play as a free player and have fun, but if you are trying to compete in pve and/or pvp you might want to pass MPQ up. There was always a pay to win aspect of the game but it wasn't that bad till the new year(2016) started and Champion Levels began and when it did I decide it was time to end my time on MPQ. I want to add that this wasn't the only thing leading up to my deature from MPQ. There were several big events I got screwed by sever issues and to put a lot of time in all week to get screwed by sever issues isn't fun. If you are a top player and in a top alliance you understand how much this matters when competing.On a side note, some of the publishers I've gotten to know during my time playing were pretty kool.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 11, 2013
												Not sure what all of the hate is about over this one.It's puzzle quest with a different theme in a F2P format. I didn't think I'd be playing this too much, but I've actually put in a good bit of time. Bit of a mix of strategy and frustration and I have not found the F2P mechanic all that limiting. If you are obsessed with advancing quickly or be able to recover instantly from a loss, yes - sooner or later you're going to need to lay some money down. As other positive reviewers have stated, develop your free characters - use your game currency for character slots and just play the game. Repeat your missions until you get all of the possible loot - some of the tutorials missions only have 1 reward, however after that they have from 2-4. After the first day or two, you should get 2 free characters from a large pool. I thought I was lucky with 2 uncommon heroes - modern hawkeye and cap, but my son received a rare spiderman and a legendary x-force wolverine. The event system has a reward structure of its own, and you can win many of the missions even with a new team. Most of the missions I have seen have a pre-assigned hero that joins you for that fight and you can leverage them to help win fights you would not normally be able to pull off. If you sink everything into 1 character you're going to be sitting around waiting for a long time if they get ko'd in a fight, so try to spread the iso-8 around when your can. Unlike PQ, you do not heal automatically after a fight. Your characters need time to heal up and this is lengthened a bit if they were ko'd. You can acquire medkits which will give you a full heal, but if you are reckless, rely too heavily on one character to win your missions - or just not very good at the game you will burn through them quckly.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2013
												First of all the time displayed about how long I've played isn't really accurate. I just have the game running in a window a lot of the time and am not playing it but it still looks to Steam like I'm playing itOK that out of the way. I see a lot of people are hating on this game and I can appreciate a lot of people will hate it because it is so very pay to win. Here's another perspective from someone who hasn't paid anything for it. I've had maybe 5 solid hours gameplay out of this, really enjoyable gameplay too. You only get so long to play free then you need more health and such and that's the point you're supposed to pay. That's the point when I leave the game.I let it recharge then come back the next time for another go. Because I can't just sit there and play for hours on end, it makes matches meaningful. A few losses are devastating and that's it for the day really but getting it right with the wins is then extremely rewarding. This game was always designed to be something you dip into and that's what I love about it. Fire it up, have a bit of fun for a short while and I'm done and back to surfing for pictures of cute cats.Now my complaints. I would really like to pay for this game because I like it. The problem is real money gets you so little its just not worth it. 5 health and enough iso8 to start to upgrade one character for £6.99 is just not good enough. Not even remotely inticing. If the DLC (lol) ever goes on sale, I'll be very interested but right now, no thanks, I'll just dip in now and again for free and enjoy what's there until its taken away

content:
Posted: December 10, 2013
												If you want to play Puzzle Quest with a Marvel paint, here you go.  It is a fun game, but there are a lot of negatives to it.  There's a large roster of characters to play with and there is some interesting strategy you can employ while playing the game, but the strategy is a bit lost in the fact you can only fight AIs.  They force you to change up your roster because characters need time to heal or revive from the last battle they've been in; this is good because loss monotany, but bad if you enjoy just playing specific characters.  It is possible to enjoy the game for free, but spending money on the game definitely gives pay players an edge over free players.I still recommend it for a fun distraction, but if you want a deeper Puzzle Quest, play puzzle quest.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												Watch out !  This game will suck your time like no other.If you like Puzzle Quest, you will love this game.  In addition to the use of Marvel characters, it also add a variety of contests.  Would have loved to share the same progress over cloud but you will have to set up different user for iphone, Ipad and PC.  Graphic wise this is like any other modern card games with beautifully rendered cards and a fairly slick interface.  Having played for over 30 hours, there is really no major story lines.  Both the story on the in-game campaigns and the tournament has very simple story lines and the dialogs are terrible.  Gameplay is where this game really shine.  If you have played Puzzle Quest, you will not exactly what to expect.  Simple to learn, hard to master.  The tournaments are somewhat skewed towards players with better cards which brings me to the freemium nature of the game.  Overall, I have not spent a single cents and it is still enjoyable.  Having said that, it is hard to compete in tournaments against people who is willing to spent some cash which is to be expected.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												Marvel + Puzzle Quest has got to be illegal.  The substance is so addictive, it's probably regulated by the government.Marvel Puzzle Quest is pretty much what it sounds like.  It's a Bejeweled-style game with Marvel Heroes.  You pick a 3-hero team and battle against a computer controlled team.  As you make matches, you gain "Action Points" to activate one of the abilities of heroes to do damage.  Whoever wipes the other team wins. There's a cash shop element, of course.  All cash-shop money can be earned in game.  Purple money is earned pretty regularly, and Gold money is earned by ranking in the tournaments.  You don't need to spend money to get anywhere in the game.  It just takes longer.The game is updated constantly.  New story events, new tournaments, and new rewards come in two or three times a week.  There's plenty to do.  I do recommend setting up a facebook account so you can gift/receive rewards that come in.  It speeds up leveling up your characters significantly.Overall, this game is a great time waster.  Give it a try.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												1 out of 5 SupervillainsI was intrigued by the concept of Puzzle Quest and I am a superhero fan. So this game has to be fantastic, right? And it is. The Bejeweled mechanic combined with special abilities works just fine. And the level system for new skills for your heroes motivates. Thumb up! (5 out of 5 Superheroes so far.)So why no recommendation and only 1 out of 5 points?1. The game is designed to be slow. Your heroes get hurt in battle and heal over time.2. Resources are scarce. Whatever you do, you have to choose on what to invest your resources.3. You get overwhelmed with opportunities. You don't have enough resources to follow each and every path at the same time.All those problems sound like good game mechanics for strategists. But they are just designed to motivate the player to pay money. I don't have a problem with a free2play game to offer options for payment. But Marvel Puzzle Quest: Dark Reign is pay2win. I tried it quite a while to see some higher hero levels and some more content. But in the end only one thing is certain: without payment you loose.You loose heroes, because you don't have enough character slots.You loose events, because your heroes don't heal fast enough, to win enough battles.And in the end, you loose either money or motivation.The game creates a highly motivating circle of simple/casual gameplay, challange, success and reward. It creates an addiction for more success. With new rewards you feel confident to beat new challanges. And the more you succeed the more you get. It's addictive.But the rewards are never enough. And you start to become frustrated.To be clear one more time: this game is designed to be pay2win. And if you don't pay, it hurts you. It is more than other free2play games for which you need more time to get better. This game makes gifts to you but if you are not good (=rich) enough, it takes them back. It destroys you, until you pay or leave.It beats you. But not on the common battlefield New York, but in your head.
