number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												The reviews for this game on Steam are generally negative, and that is unfair. This is a free to play game, that does feature strong incentives to spend on microtransactions, and that is, indeed, hatefull. I am the first to agree that something is very wrong in the industry right now regarding the f2p model. However, I believe a game should still be judged by how good a game it is in its own right. And this match 3 game is, in that regard, quite spectacular. The implementation of the original puzzle quest design is great, the look and feel of the game is pleasing and professional (it looks way better than puzzle quest 2, and better than most games of the genre), and there is a deep strategic level to the gameplay, which is quite surprising. Moreover, the use of the Marvel IP is clever. There is a pretty nice story going on, which is tied up with events on the comics, with the intentional cheesy but great dialogues that are a staple of the genre. Collecting your favorite heroes from Marvel universe is a fun activity in itself. There is a good variety of heroes, from both X-men and Avengers comics, alongside playable villains and rarer heroes (Punisher and Invisible Woman, for instance). Each hero play different, with obvious dps, tank and support roles, so that finding a team that works well together, and the right way to level them so they will interplay efficiently, is an interesting challenge. It delivers on all its promisses, being both a good Marvel game, and a good, a very good indeed, Puzzle game. It's microtransactions scheme is a big flaw, something I wish I would never encounter in any other game again. Unfortunately, that is where the industry is right now, and it is killing otherwise great games.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												Unless you have HEAPS of time, or are willing to not advance in a LONG time, you shouldn't invest time in this game. For starters, the "story mode" is pretty much limited, and frankly, subpar. To continue, the brunt of the game is PVP. The basics of the game are 2 days tournaments, after which you earn some prize based on your position. You can get some minor rewards based on performance. But here's the thing. You'll be fighting random people, some of them have spent thousands of dollars in this game, and are pretty much unbeatable, making a free player unable to get in the top 10.Also the game lies in the avaliable languages department. Yes, it says it's in spanish... and the game is right... as long as you call spanish something with untranslated lines of text, and has blind idiot translations (check tvtropes) for the rest of it. I mean "Ironman se parte"? You'd need "Ironman breaks himself"/"Ironman shatters himself"/"Ironman laughs his♥♥♥♥♥off" for that. And yes, "Ironman laughs his♥♥♥♥♥off" is what spanish readers will read. It's quite a funny idea, having all these heroes laughing at each other. Power descriptions are quite inacurate, too. I have to assume that every other language is riddled with these bad translation issues, but can't say for sure. The Spanish translation, at least, is even worse than using google translator. So there's that.There's also the luck factor. Sometimes luck is against you. I know that it's par for the course in a puzzle-quest game, but, for the heck of it, I spent literally 4 minutes watching how the computer cascaded after removing 3 piezes on the uppermost line. That kind of luck means you'll have to spend at least one hour and a half waiting for recovery packs, in order to try another game.And that's the final issue for me: Downtime. In every battle, for the most part, you'll get hurt, at least a little. And then you need to spend downtime recovering. At first, it doesn't look like it's too much. five minutes or so, for the first few levels. Then you level up, and notice that the recovery rate isn't based on a percentual of the heroes' health, but on their individual hitpoints. So if you happen to have a heroe with 7000 hitpoints, be ready for waiting a few hours... or spend some money to recover it. Well, you get health packs every 35 minutes... But even so, that means you'll be playing 5 minutes, waiting almost 2 hours. That would be perfectly ok for a mobile game. Just play once while on the bus/subway, and forget aboit it while working. But as a pc game it fails horribly.So, as I said, unless you're willing to play 2 or 3 games a day, or pay a LOT of money, don't bother with this game.

content:
Posted: December 9, 2013
												Everyone brings up the microtransactions, and they ARE pretty excessive.  It's hard not to get stickershock looking at a package of fake money that costs $100 of REAL money, but I think there are some more fundamental things wrong with the game, at least at this point:1) It's hard to tell what's going on, who is getting damaged, etc.  Feedback, which was super clear in the original Puzzle Quest, is really poor in this version.2) Given all the microtransactions and the cross-platform nature of the game, it bugs me that I can't access the same account from my phone as from my Steam account, and that the game isn't even aware of my progress if I log on from a different Steam machine.  3) The game has a lot of the bugs inherent in an early launch, including bugs and weirdness.  The game is clearly meant to allow players to use an Xbox 360 controller, but parts of it, including tutorials, break -- sometimes badly -- when using the controller.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												A perfect example of how being made 'free-to-play' can utterly destroy an otherwise greatly enjoyable game.In fairness, this was always going to be a little novelty title that people wouldn't pay much for, and would only play in small doses. But it IS a fun game. At least until you have a bad round, and your heroes take so much damage during the a five minute or less match that you then can't play it again for over half an hour (unless, of course, you fork out some real-world cash for the privilege).Trying to collect as many heroes as possible is similarly frustrating, as the story missions give you plenty of opportunities to gain more, yet far fewer opportunities to gain the particular in-game currency you need to expand your roster size so that you can actually fit the extra heroes the game keeps trying to throw at you. Though once again, the game is always quick to suggest you could avoid this inconvenience if you'd just whip out your credit card.Despite all this, I will reiterate that the game is enjoyable. So I would heartily recommend giving it a try _IF_ you can either police yourself to never playing for more than maybe 10 minutes in a session, you're happy to regularly alt-tab out or read a book for half an hour between matches, or you're the kind of person who doesn't mind sinking hundreds of dollars into a minor distraction for features that you'd expect a $5 game to come with as standard.If not, save yourself the frustration and don't bother.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2013
												If you want to play Puzzle Quest with a Marvel paint, here you go.  It is a fun game, but there are a lot of negatives to it.  There's a large roster of characters to play with and there is some interesting strategy you can employ while playing the game, but the strategy is a bit lost in the fact you can only fight AIs.  They force you to change up your roster because characters need time to heal or revive from the last battle they've been in; this is good because loss monotany, but bad if you enjoy just playing specific characters.  It is possible to enjoy the game for free, but spending money on the game definitely gives pay players an edge over free players.I still recommend it for a fun distraction, but if you want a deeper Puzzle Quest, play puzzle quest.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 10, 2013
												This game is surprisingly fun.  The character abilities are a bit limited but being able to level them and the character itself allows for the challenge level to develope without crippling you.  Basic mechanics are solid and, while luck is a huge factor like any simple match 3 game, there is definitely room for strategy.  Is the game perfect.  Heck no.  There are too few character slots so you wind up either selling a ton of characters or paying some cash to make room for them.  However, you can play the game for a while without spending cash if you are willing to grind rewards a bit.Play the game, have some fun and then spend a little to support the effort.  When you hit a wall that requires a serious investment, move on to a new game.

content:

												First of all the time displayed about how long I've played isn't really accurate. I just have the game running in a window a lot of the time and am not playing it but it still looks to Steam like I'm playing itOK that out of the way. I see a lot of people are hating on this game and I can appreciate a lot of people will hate it because it is so very pay to win. Here's another perspective from someone who hasn't paid anything for it. I've had maybe 5 solid hours gameplay out of this, really enjoyable gameplay too. You only get so long to play free then you need more health and such and that's the point you're supposed to pay. That's the point when I leave the game.I let it recharge then come back the next time for another go. Because I can't just sit there and play for hours on end, it makes matches meaningful. A few losses are devastating and that's it for the day really but getting it right with the wins is then extremely rewarding. This game was always designed to be something you dip into and that's what I love about it. Fire it up, have a bit of fun for a short while and I'm done and back to surfing for pictures of cute cats.Now my complaints. I would really like to pay for this game because I like it. The problem is real money gets you so little its just not worth it. 5 health and enough iso8 to start to upgrade one character for £6.99 is just not good enough. Not even remotely inticing. If the DLC (lol) ever goes on sale, I'll be very interested but right now, no thanks, I'll just dip in now and again for free and enjoy what's there until its taken away

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
												The game is a bad iOS thing, better suited for a touchscreen than a monitor. The speechbubbles are gigantic and it seems to out of place. With an interface clearly designed for touchscreen. The game can be played without sinking money into, and there are some possibilities to earn the Money Currency but overall you are strongly incentivised to buy the boosterpacks. The good and rare heros seem to be hidden inside the money bags and not obtainable via ingame currency.The prologue is horribly written, with Ironman trying to be funny and overall displaying what i would call his Movie Personality. The writing of the story is bad. To the point where one ends up just pressing the Skip button.There isn't much to be said for the mechanics, as the whole game is just a basic match3 mechanic. The music got repretitive real quick and the fact that if your hero gets damaged you have to wait up to an hour or use an item in order to keep playing. You can't even decide to keep playing with a damaged hero. Like missing 20 HP of a 300HP bar, takes 5 minutes to heal up, but wouldn't let me start a match going into it with a damaged hero.They should have left the game on iOS devices, its most certainly not a game to be played on a widescreen monitor or even bigger screens like Big Screen Mode.And as i mentioned twice so far. The game gives upgrades via boosterpacks. New Abilities are unlocked by finding a variant of the hero you already have. Some can be obtained through play, but the rest are expected to be bought via gambling packs. You have no control over which hero you get. Want to play a Team with your favorit Heroes? Good look getting them. There isn't even a trade system, so you could trade them with someone else. You'll probably end up sinking a bunch of money into it, in order to get your dream team of heroes. The pricing of the packs feels like a rip off to me. With Trading Card Games i not only have the option to trade the cards, but also i understand they have to be printed. Here i got no option to trade cards, or non i saw, and since seem to have only a limited amount of heroes i could have with me, and no obvious option to buy more slots, you probably just end up playing with whatever hero you end up with.As a Match 3 game, i find the soundtrack unappealing and yeah, its a F2P Match3 game designed for iOS. If thats what you are looking for, don't be discouraged by Marvel heroes. As Marvel Fan... give this a pass, you won't be getting what you coming for.

												My experience so far...The first hour was fun! Really, really fun! The second hour wasn't bad. The third hour, I'd realized that in fact, yes, you CAN play all the way through a game where you're only "unlock" for that level left is a cover or charicter token, and get a 20 crystal card several times in a row for no discurnable reason instead. So, that's kinda a problem.Do you like choosing between laying out significant real world money? Do you like deleting charicters you've spent hours leveling up? Do you like deleting charicters you JUST got in a drop but don't have a space left to play with it? If you can answer "yes" to one of those questions, this is a great game for you.Honestly, if I could get the entire game for $15-20, I'd say go for it. It's a fun little puzzle game...but I wouldn't put a dime into this game.

												I played this game almost 2 years. I managed to get a maxed out top tier (4 star) character after ONE YEAR of heavy grinding. I initially spent 20 bucks, but soon realized that spending money doesn't help at all. The better you get, the tougher the game gets.I got a second maxed top tier character after 15 month, but he wasn't what he used to be, because they nerfed him shortly before. content:
Posted: February 18, 2015
												Match-three meets Micro-transactions meets CCG mechanics. Free to Play but also Pay to Win.Cons: -Storyline virtually inexistent-Brings nothing new to the genre -Does not delivers especially well what's been done better in other games of the same genre-Worst thing about it? Everything about this game feels like a test of endurance in ''How long will you hold out until you succumb and spend money''. Pros:FreeRecommendations:I would recommend the average consumer to avoid this product, although I have to admit that someone who actively enjoys the feeling of ''outsmarting'' the game design of Free To Play/Pay To Win titles might get a good number of hours of entertainment out of it.Actual length of content:As the game is updated regularly, with game modes coming and going, the actual length depends greatly on the consumer's personal tolerance for that genre and its repetition more than the available  I personnally checked out after less than 3 hours even though I must have spent more than 300 hours on similar titles.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 10, 2014
												I have been playing this for awhile on PC and android. I am by no means an expert, but I think I can bring a more reasonable spin on things. I think one thing people kind of gloss over, is that the game is not final. My overall impression of the game is positive. It is a fun low-commitment game. By that I mean the more you approach it casually from a time and money perspective, the more you will like it. Yes, this game is pay-to-win, but if you do that then there really is no reason to play this game. The game is entirely about improving your characters. It is not about PVE or PVP(more on that later). Yes, there are annoying cockblocks that preventprogression, so then do not do so. Consider it an appetizer for your main course, whatever game you are really playing. This is the kind of game you play when you are about ready to go to bed, or that moment right after you turn on your pc or tablet. I would say this game works better as a mobile game, quick and dirty gaming, but the UI is much better in the PC version. Pros:-Graphics and effects are nice. The artstyle in particular is noteworthy, if this was a comic series I would pick it up. -The game is in beta, so the developers are still improving the game. For example, attacks and effects used to happen much more slowly, but now they are instantaneous. The UI in the android version used to be truly terrible, but they have added little changes that make it less tedious to track abilities and AP. There is hope for improvement, and I doubt development costs for improvements for such a simple game are so large that change will never come. -If you are a Marvel fan, I am sorry to say this, but this is probably the best comic book game available to you. This is no Arkham City, but fun can still be had here.-The core gameplay is fun and easy to get into. Once you know what you are doing, it is fast and strangely satisfying. That is, before the inevitable wall, but we went over that already.Cons:-The fact that it is pay-2-win is not the issue, the fact that "PVP" is forced on you is. Pay 2 win is only an issue in PVP games, for singleplayer games who really cares, and that is how I want to play this. What I mean by this is that PVE offers a very limited means of upgrading your characters. You will never get enough ISO, HP or character covers to upgrade your best toons by PVE alone, it is more practice for PVP with forgetabble storylines. You will get plenty of low level character covers here to upgrade, but the daily rewards will start overwhelming you to the point where you are forced to "compete". -PVP is not really PVP. Like most mobile PVP games, you are really just fighting representations of other players characters. So, not only are you forced to PVP, it is not even real PVP. Oh, so who are you really fighting? An extremely sketchy AI. The AI is so sketchy in PVP and events it is hilarious. Cascade after cascade awaits you. This is to counter the fact that there is no true skill matchmaking, you will find your level 15 toons up against level 40 toons, uh no thanks. You can skip these guys, in fact you as the attacker have every advantage. You pick the team, you get to use upgrades, and you get to skip. That is probably why the AI cheats so much. Oh, and apparently your team is whatever team you last used, which is never explained to you.-Nothing is explained to you. You probably read a lot of the above thinking what is this person talking about. This is what the game does, it only explains a very basic notion of the game. You kind of have to learn from your mistakes as you go. They never explain important things like the limited amount of points available to upgrade a toon, imagine if you paid to max out a character and found out you put too many points in the wrong talent, I bet you would be pretty upset since you would have to start from scratch.-A lot of this game is just luck. Upgrades, prizes, even combat can often come down to good old RNG. If you are like me, I hate RNG with a passion. You have no control over the colors of the gems in this game, but I am sure the AI you will face does. In fact, count on it. Just make sure you have a team that can utilize the colors of the spectrum. You see a lot of cons there, I often want to quit, but then something happens to pull me back in. This game is a continuous carrot-on-a-stick game, which is not surprising given that it is free. I think at minimum you will definitely need to drop some money for character slots, it is very hard to get around that. You will want to quit often, but then they will give you a free 3 star card and you will say, "maybe another chance". But, like I said earlier, a little perspective helps a lot. Do not try and "beat" this game, and you will enjoy it. It is a good time killer, not a time filler.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												Unless you have HEAPS of time, or are willing to not advance in a LONG time, you shouldn't invest time in this game. For starters, the "story mode" is pretty much limited, and frankly, subpar. To continue, the brunt of the game is PVP. The basics of the game are 2 days tournaments, after which you earn some prize based on your position. You can get some minor rewards based on performance. But here's the thing. You'll be fighting random people, some of them have spent thousands of dollars in this game, and are pretty much unbeatable, making a free player unable to get in the top 10.Also the game lies in the avaliable languages department. Yes, it says it's in spanish... and the game is right... as long as you call spanish something with untranslated lines of text, and has blind idiot translations (check tvtropes) for the rest of it. I mean "Ironman se parte"? You'd need "Ironman breaks himself"/"Ironman shatters himself"/"Ironman laughs his♥♥♥♥♥off" for that. And yes, "Ironman laughs his♥♥♥♥♥off" is what spanish readers will read. It's quite a funny idea, having all these heroes laughing at each other. Power descriptions are quite inacurate, too. I have to assume that every other language is riddled with these bad translation issues, but can't say for sure. The Spanish translation, at least, is even worse than using google translator. So there's that.There's also the luck factor. Sometimes luck is against you. I know that it's par for the course in a puzzle-quest game, but, for the heck of it, I spent literally 4 minutes watching how the computer cascaded after removing 3 piezes on the uppermost line. That kind of luck means you'll have to spend at least one hour and a half waiting for recovery packs, in order to try another game.And that's the final issue for me: Downtime. In every battle, for the most part, you'll get hurt, at least a little. And then you need to spend downtime recovering. At first, it doesn't look like it's too much. five minutes or so, for the first few levels. Then you level up, and notice that the recovery rate isn't based on a percentual of the heroes' health, but on their individual hitpoints. So if you happen to have a heroe with 7000 hitpoints, be ready for waiting a few hours... or spend some money to recover it. Well, you get health packs every 35 minutes... But even so, that means you'll be playing 5 minutes, waiting almost 2 hours. That would be perfectly ok for a mobile game. Just play once while on the bus/subway, and forget aboit it while working. But as a pc game it fails horribly.So, as I said, unless you're willing to play 2 or 3 games a day, or pay a LOT of money, don't bother with this game.

												The short version. If you like match-3 games, you can get this. If you like Puzzle Quest, you should get this. If you like Marvel heroes and Puzzle Quest you have to get this. If you don't like Puzzle Quest, don't bother.Now to add a few things. The game is free to play and you can get along without paying any money for quite some time. If you are not a very competitive kind of person you can get lots of fun from the game and not pay any money at all, ever. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												Yes, it's pay2win. Yes, it's even pay2play when you're first playing. It doesn't require you to pay money for anything, it just makes it so you don't have to wait. Yes, coming from Puzzle Quest 2, or Galactix it's extremely annoying that you can't sit down for 4 hours at a time and grind through levels. Once you get past those major complaints (and they are valid) you find a fun puzzle quest game. The art is fun, variety a good time. The only real issue (aside from those very real complaints I listed) is once you find a playstyle, 90% of the characters you find in game are useless (I'm looking at you Spiderman). The missions that come in every day/week force you to change it up, though I still find myself going back to my normal crew when able. Remember, this started life as an iPhone game, so treat it as such - play 5-10 minutes at a time, and you won't have the complaints most see.

												I wasn't sure if I'd like this game or not.  In general, I like casual games; howeverI had seen reviews that said players had to do a lot of grinding.  I'm going to give this 3 (of 5) Stars.That translates to postive/recommended, with caveats.I enjoy the Match 3 play, with the strategic elements they have addedbased on Marvel's Graphic Novel mythos.  However, its a very slowstart as a new player to build up your characters/slots, and the bestoppurtunities to improve them do mean you spend a fair amount of time"grinding" during specific multiplayer competitions/events.  This, of course,encourages PAY-TO-PLAY aspects of the game.UPDATE:  I've been playing this game, almost daily, for a couple of months now.  The grinding is constant.  Even when you "win" a major event (I came in #2 once), the prizes help you a lot if you were starting out but don't change your ability to succeed very much at all most of the time.I now think this game has been optimized for Pay2Play.  I'm lowering my score to 2/5, and changing my recommendation to NO.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												A simple match'n drop puzzle game.  I enjoy it.  Great for casual play, considering my other most played is DOTA2, where you are locked into a 30-70 minute match with nine others ... pausing can be impractical there.  On Marvel PQ, you can just walk away and make your sandwich, check on the kids, come back and pick up where you left it.The game play has a few bells and whistles, nothing inventive for the genre.  I do enjoy grinding out rewards and new heroes though.  Many would call this a pay-to-win.  If you go that route, you are investing hundreds of dollars.  I enjoy unlocking everything through matches won ... and they have several "special events" each week to compete for the free unlocks.If you already have some intensive action games on your most played, and would like a relaxing puzzle solver to fill in between matches, or when you are to busy to commit hours at a time, I highly recommend this F2P.  Also works on the smartphone, though the interface is a little clunky there, IMHO.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												I have played this game since very, very shortly after it came out on Android, and was just absolutely ecstatic to see it come to the Steam platform. I will admit, I honestly wasn't entirely certain how well it would translate between the platforms, but they did wonderfully and, honestly, it's an even better game on PC than on mobile, in my opinion. I've been a huge fan of Puzzle Quest since Challenge of the Warlords, and when I first found this game on mobile I'd honestly been looking for a Puzzle Quest game rather than the ports of their existing games which were either "free" but made you pay to get anywhere and were terrible ports anyway, or up-front costs that I wasn't willing to pay since I'd already bought a couple copies of the games already (3 for prior phones, and Android versions were the priciest yet). So I was therefore absolutely delighted to see this new release and hadn't expected it to be much more than a traditional Puzzle Quest game with some Marvel characters slapped on to make it sell better but otherwise not really changing anything, and I would have been happy enough with that - however, much to my surprise, lo and behold it was an exquisite melding of the two worlds to create something better than both alone. The game has since captured my attention and kept me rapt with excitement for hours on end, laughing at the writing as I read along about the characters I already know and love in new stories and situations, on both platforms, as I match away and watch my Marvel heroes absolutely own face after some TLC and level-ups. I absolutely cannot recommend this game enough if you have any interest in puzzlers or Puzzle Quest-like games.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2013
												It's a pretty cool game, though they still need to do a lot to improve it.First, let's talk about "freemium". This is one of those games where you can buy tokens to get things faster. That's fine. But the prices are so outrageously expensive (as are most freemium games) that there's not a chance in hell that I'm going to actually buy anything. The prices are so high that it's clear that their only interest is in milking stupid people and teenagers (but I repeat myself) for every coin they own. And they'll make a lot of money doing that. I just wish the rest of us could play. The prices are set high, to milk about 5% of their players, while other people who are willing to pay (like me) are too smart to pay their current absurd prices. So, it's not going to last me more than a week, because they don't want my business.Second, ever heard of tooltips? Right-clicking? Apparently this game's programmers haven't. I know it's basically a port of a mobile game, but that doesn't excuse anything.All of its problems aside, it's actually a fun game, and I really enjoy collecting and leveling characters. But again, I wish they would allow me to participate more in that.UPDATE: I played for a while after I wrote this, and discovered that after a certain point, it's impossible to progress without paying absurd amounts of money for characters, skills, character slots, etc., so I had to change my recommendation to "no".I'm not expecting this game to be 100% free, but I do expect it to be reasonably affordable.

												Great game, lots of fun. Recommend when you first start you concentrate on leveling up good guys. You may get the opportunity to get Daken (Wolverines son) and a couple other of the Dark Avengers, but i wouldn't invest too much iso on them at the start. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												EDIT (07-29-14): I decided to go back and check out the game after a lengthy hiatus to see if any of the ridiculous balance issues had been addressed. Unfortunately, these issues seem to be worse now than months ago, when I originally quit playing. Enemy teams will almost always get multiple lines per turn and always get whatever color gems they need to drop at precisely the right time to keep their combos going to 2, 3 or 4x After uninstalling today I can safely say I'll not ever be going back. Marvel really should be ashamed of themselves.There are a few things you should consider before jumping to Marvel Puzzle Quest: Dark Reign.1) Do you mind only playing in small, bite-sized chunks?2) Do you mind spending real-world cash to continue playing?If you answered "no" to the first question then have at it. You'll have fun building your deck of characters, leveling them up, taking on new challenges, etc. It's essentially the old Puzzle Quest with a Marvel spin, which isn't a bad thing. It's quite fun if you enjoy that type of game and completing challenges and quest lines is rewarding.If you answered "yes" to the second question then prepare to be sorely disappointed. You can play this game without ever spending a single cent, but you won't have the best characters, won't have enough storage space for additional characters, won't be able to level them high enough to compete in multiplayer events and will always be running short on health packs. Basically, without spending money on it (and not just once, but regularly) you'll never get the most out of it.D3 and Demiurge took the exact same iOS/Adroid game, complete with it's heavy insistance on rampant microtransactions, and ported it to PC. It's a rather shameful cash-grab, in terms of milking players for as much money as possible, but underneath all the negatives is a solid, enjoyable game. It's just too bad you have to dig through so much bad to get to the good.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
												The game is a bad iOS thing, better suited for a touchscreen than a monitor. The speechbubbles are gigantic and it seems to out of place. With an interface clearly designed for touchscreen. The game can be played without sinking money into, and there are some possibilities to earn the Money Currency but overall you are strongly incentivised to buy the boosterpacks. The good and rare heros seem to be hidden inside the money bags and not obtainable via ingame currency.The prologue is horribly written, with Ironman trying to be funny and overall displaying what i would call his Movie Personality. The writing of the story is bad. To the point where one ends up just pressing the Skip button.There isn't much to be said for the mechanics, as the whole game is just a basic match3 mechanic. The music got repretitive real quick and the fact that if your hero gets damaged you have to wait up to an hour or use an item in order to keep playing. You can't even decide to keep playing with a damaged hero. Like missing 20 HP of a 300HP bar, takes 5 minutes to heal up, but wouldn't let me start a match going into it with a damaged hero.They should have left the game on iOS devices, its most certainly not a game to be played on a widescreen monitor or even bigger screens like Big Screen Mode.And as i mentioned twice so far. The game gives upgrades via boosterpacks. New Abilities are unlocked by finding a variant of the hero you already have. Some can be obtained through play, but the rest are expected to be bought via gambling packs. You have no control over which hero you get. Want to play a Team with your favorit Heroes? Good look getting them. There isn't even a trade system, so you could trade them with someone else. You'll probably end up sinking a bunch of money into it, in order to get your dream team of heroes. The pricing of the packs feels like a rip off to me. With Trading Card Games i not only have the option to trade the cards, but also i understand they have to be printed. Here i got no option to trade cards, or non i saw, and since seem to have only a limited amount of heroes i could have with me, and no obvious option to buy more slots, you probably just end up playing with whatever hero you end up with.As a Match 3 game, i find the soundtrack unappealing and yeah, its a F2P Match3 game designed for iOS. If thats what you are looking for, don't be discouraged by Marvel heroes. As Marvel Fan... give this a pass, you won't be getting what you coming for.

												My experience so far...The first hour was fun! Really, really fun! The second hour wasn't bad. Do you like deleting charicters you JUST got in a drop but don't have a space left to play with it? If you can answer "yes" to one of those questions, this is a great game for you.Honestly, if I could get the entire game for $15-20, I'd say go for it. It's a fun little puzzle game...but I wouldn't put a dime into this game.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2013
												If you want to play Puzzle Quest with a Marvel paint, here you go.  It is a fun game, but there are a lot of negatives to it.  There's a large roster of characters to play with and there is some interesting strategy you can employ while playing the game, but the strategy is a bit lost in the fact you can only fight AIs.  They force you to change up your roster because characters need time to heal or revive from the last battle they've been in; this is good because loss monotany, but bad if you enjoy just playing specific characters.  It is possible to enjoy the game for free, but spending money on the game definitely gives pay players an edge over free players.I still recommend it for a fun distraction, but if you want a deeper Puzzle Quest, play puzzle quest.

												Judging by a /massive/ negative feedback this game seems to generate in the review section, this is going to be unpopular.To begin with, there is a false belief that the game is purely pay to win. In my humble opinion, that is totally untrue. Sure, the game offers a lot of things that make gameplay easier for irl cash.But the core elements, are completely free to play. I mean, it's a friggin match-three gameplay, they don't tell you to pay for borad smasher or something similar. Even the cards can be obtained without paying anything, just by playing the game.What is more the things that you pay money for, are largely irrelevant in the grand scheme of things, as even the PvP is in fact done vs not-a-human.The only problem, is the health regen ratio for characters.

												This game is an unholy mess of microtransactions and monotonous grinding. It's 'free to play' but if you want to have any kind of fun they expect you to fork out on massive amounts of DLC otherwise you will have to grind for 30 hours to even have a chance of getting something you actually want. If you have half a brain I advise you to avoid it like the plague. The business model is designed to bleed people dry and these types of games should not be encouraged.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 9, 2013
												Everyone brings up the microtransactions, and they ARE pretty excessive.  It's hard not to get stickershock looking at a package of fake money that costs $100 of REAL money, but I think there are some more fundamental things wrong with the game, at least at this point:1) It's hard to tell what's going on, who is getting damaged, etc.  Feedback, which was super clear in the original Puzzle Quest, is really poor in this version.2) Given all the microtransactions and the cross-platform nature of the game, it bugs me that I can't access the same account from my phone as from my Steam account, and that the game isn't even aware of my progress if I log on from a different Steam machine.  3) The game has a lot of the bugs inherent in an early launch, including bugs and weirdness.  The game is clearly meant to allow players to use an Xbox 360 controller, but parts of it, including tutorials, break -- sometimes badly -- when using the controller.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												A perfect example of how being made 'free-to-play' can utterly destroy an otherwise greatly enjoyable game.In fairness, this was always going to be a little novelty title that people wouldn't pay much for, and would only play in small doses. But it IS a fun game. At least until you have a bad round, and your heroes take so much damage during the a five minute or less match that you then can't play it again for over half an hour (unless, of course, you fork out some real-world cash for the privilege).Trying to collect as many heroes as possible is similarly frustrating, as the story missions give you plenty of opportunities to gain more, yet far fewer opportunities to gain the particular in-game currency you need to expand your roster size so that you can actually fit the extra heroes the game keeps trying to throw at you. Though once again, the game is always quick to suggest you could avoid this inconvenience if you'd just whip out your credit card.Despite all this, I will reiterate that the game is enjoyable. So I would heartily recommend giving it a try _IF_ you can either police yourself to never playing for more than maybe 10 minutes in a session, you're happy to regularly alt-tab out or read a book for half an hour between matches, or you're the kind of person who doesn't mind sinking hundreds of dollars into a minor distraction for features that you'd expect a $5 game to come with as standard.If not, save yourself the frustration and don't bother.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												I have played this game since very, very shortly after it came out on Android, and was just absolutely ecstatic to see it come to the Steam platform. I will admit, I honestly wasn't entirely certain how well it would translate between the platforms, but they did wonderfully and, honestly, it's an even better game on PC than on mobile, in my opinion. I've been a huge fan of Puzzle Quest since Challenge of the Warlords, and when I first found this game on mobile I'd honestly been looking for a Puzzle Quest game rather than the ports of their existing games which were either "free" but made you pay to get anywhere and were terrible ports anyway, or up-front costs that I wasn't willing to pay since I'd already bought a couple copies of the games already (3 for prior phones, and Android versions were the priciest yet). So I was therefore absolutely delighted to see this new release and hadn't expected it to be much more than a traditional Puzzle Quest game with some Marvel characters slapped on to make it sell better but otherwise not really changing anything, and I would have been happy enough with that - however, much to my surprise, lo and behold it was an exquisite melding of the two worlds to create something better than both alone. The game has since captured my attention and kept me rapt with excitement for hours on end, laughing at the writing as I read along about the characters I already know and love in new stories and situations, on both platforms, as I match away and watch my Marvel heroes absolutely own face after some TLC and level-ups. I absolutely cannot recommend this game enough if you have any interest in puzzlers or Puzzle Quest-like games.

												Fun for very casual play but will quickly become frustrating if you are unwilling to constantly buy points.  A good game for someone who wants to play only a few minutes at a time but not for the person who wants to sit down and play for hours straight.  This is the kind of game you get to play for a short amount of time and you will need to wait for your characters to heal.  You may of course pay ungodly amounts of money to speed things along.  If you are going to spend money on points I suggest you only buy the gold coins to unlock roster spots.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
												I personally enjoyed this.  While the game does push microtransactions at every turn, to buy slots for heroes, to merely upgrade heroes and beyond, I still got enjoyment out of this game.  That being said, the actual puzzle quest titles are better, solely for the reason that they are games you've already paid for, thus play differently.To actually get a hero, you'll have to have a comic book cover for them. To actually make said hero practical, you'd will search for 10-13 covers for each hero. In turn, you get a ton of comic book covers from all sorts of sources. It would be nice to have something to do with the 10's or 100's of covers, for heroes you've already maxed out, other than selling them for 100 ISO. It would be nice to perhaps combine 5 1-star covers for a 2 star cover, for example.The hero slots are also quite limited, requiring premium currency to expand. That being said, by spending all the hero coins the game gives you on those slots, getting 10 slots of heroes is fairly manageable. You can get a lot of coins from events, as well as set rewards. It would be nice to have more of those rewards though. With the current event to recruit the Hulk, it's quite annoying when most of the level options are marked as 'impossible' since there isn't much for scaling. The difficulty might give a general idea, but it's far from accurate. I'm not sure if the difficulty marker is for my top heroes, or the current line up from the previous battle. It's far from perfect, but playing a game I haven't paid for I'm expecting some rough edges. This is rougher than most.  To give a scale of how much I enjoyed this game, it would range between 6 and 7.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 15, 2013
												It's a pretty cool game, though they still need to do a lot to improve it.First, let's talk about "freemium". This is one of those games where you can buy tokens to get things faster. That's fine. But the prices are so outrageously expensive (as are most freemium games) that there's not a chance in hell that I'm going to actually buy anything. The prices are so high that it's clear that their only interest is in milking stupid people and teenagers (but I repeat myself) for every coin they own. And they'll make a lot of money doing that. I just wish the rest of us could play. The prices are set high, to milk about 5% of their players, while other people who are willing to pay (like me) are too smart to pay their current absurd prices. So, it's not going to last me more than a week, because they don't want my business.Second, ever heard of tooltips? Right-clicking? Apparently this game's programmers haven't. I know it's basically a port of a mobile game, but that doesn't excuse anything.All of its problems aside, it's actually a fun game, and I really enjoy collecting and leveling characters. But again, I wish they would allow me to participate more in that.UPDATE: I played for a while after I wrote this, and discovered that after a certain point, it's impossible to progress without paying absurd amounts of money for characters, skills, character slots, etc., so I had to change my recommendation to "no".I'm not expecting this game to be 100% free, but I do expect it to be reasonably affordable.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												Puzzle Quest will turn you into a zombie, with the addition of Marvel... you shoud inform your next of kin you will be missing for a long, long timeUnfortunately this title has been heavily tuned to Grabbing your cash to an extent that after a few hours of play, its quite clear that this is indeed a pay to keep playing title. As your characters need healing after battle,  you only get 5 free heals a day... and thats where the money leaching starts...Not Free to Play, Not Pay to Win, this is like an old arcade machine where it will continue to suck your wallet dry as long as you want to stay and play.This is a Pay to Play title. Completely miscategorized. I'm not saying its a game you have to purchase, I'm saying its a game that will continuously bleed you dry everyday. For an addict this is the worst possible type of game, and it shouldn't be on steam. There is only one free to play option, download and play the first few nooby rounds. However; once you start building out any character it becomes clear: the monster in the room is the health cycle. You could sit back and wait 3 hours for your heroes to heal, or you can pay .50 cents per heal, per character, so this game could cost $1.50 a round with no perk characters granted, or an average of $1.00 per round. That is if you dont want to wait 3 hours after your 5 free heals are used. This is a Puzzle Quest tittle, anyone familiar with the series will know that it takes an incredible amount of grinding to build any character. Bottom line is this game would cost a small fortune to master, or to make it to the top of the player charts...Is it worth it? I dont think so. As much as I am a fan of Puzzle Quest and Marvel, this game truely punishes the player ( and wallet ). This is actually a blight on the series with this type of pay to play structure. I believe this title was programmed to rake cash.Disgraceful. Uninstalled promptly after writing this, and will not likely ever reinstall.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 10, 2013
												Not a terrible game as the mass of negative reviews may indivate, however, there are some major drawbacks which certain gamers won't get on with.The Bad:1) Filled with "micro"payments (not that micro really...) where you can pay to get ahead.2) Although the steam version was released 5 days ago, you're competing with iOS players who have obviously had a long time to play. They have more stuff, better characters, and there's many PvP tournaments to unlock more, better, characters which are virtually unobtainable due to their inherent advantage. If you were to pay to get yourself competitive, you'd be looking at paying thousands of pounds. Maybe they could have given Steam users a boost, or segregated the communities or had steam only contests so it's at least level?3) There's a lot of required characters for limited time events. Some are provided for use in certain battles, but I've found limited time games blocked from me because I don't have Iron Man Mk40.4) There's nothing original here, it's the same old game with some Marvel characters.5) It takes gold to unlock more character slots. Gold is available in finite amounts from the various single player and PvP events, but frustratingly once you receive a character card you are given 7 days to put it in your roster (either by increasing the roster or destroying an existing character card) else you lose your new character. It appears more characters have been added over time, as iOS players gathered enough gold to boost their slots. As a steam player this is a further handicap.6) Your characters have health which regenerates over time, but if they're K/O'd in battle, you lose them for an hour or more as they regenerate. You have 5 health packs for an instant revive, and a new health pack generates every 36 minutes. This does allow you to keep going, but you may find as you get into the game you are reluctant to try harder battles because your team will take damage which means you'll have to stop playing for a while. This is more designed for players who have half an hour to kill at regular intervals, rather than someone who wants to play solidly.The Good:1) It is puzzle quest, and it's free (sort of) so if you can resist paying, it's not bad.2) Since the iOS players have such an advantage, you're never competitive so there's less of a compulsion to be right up there. This makes it easier not to pay, and if you enjoy the challenge of being an underdog, it's not bad. Of course, if you're naturally very competitive you'll hate this game because there's no way you can do that without spending a sum which could be better used as a deposit on a mortgage.3) The game appears solid and bug free.4) It is simple enough to leave the game running in the background as your team heals when you do other things.I'd probably give this about 4/10, and would only recommend it to fans of Marvel, casual gamers who like CandyCrush/Bejewelled, and anyone wanting a free to play game who can resist the urge to pay for in game purchases. This is nothing special, it's a run of the mill game designed to milk money from gamers, but it can still be fun.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
												I personally enjoyed this.  While the game does push microtransactions at every turn, to buy slots for heroes, to merely upgrade heroes and beyond, I still got enjoyment out of this game.  That being said, the actual puzzle quest titles are better, solely for the reason that they are games you've already paid for, thus play differently.To actually get a hero, you'll have to have a comic book cover for them. To actually make said hero practical, you'd will search for 10-13 covers for each hero. In turn, you get a ton of comic book covers from all sorts of sources. It would be nice to have something to do with the 10's or 100's of covers, for heroes you've already maxed out, other than selling them for 100 ISO. It would be nice to perhaps combine 5 1-star covers for a 2 star cover, for example.The hero slots are also quite limited, requiring premium currency to expand. That being said, by spending all the hero coins the game gives you on those slots, getting 10 slots of heroes is fairly manageable. You can get a lot of coins from events, as well as set rewards. It would be nice to have more of those rewards though. With the current event to recruit the Hulk, it's quite annoying when most of the level options are marked as 'impossible' since there isn't much for scaling. The difficulty might give a general idea, but it's far from accurate. I'm not sure if the difficulty marker is for my top heroes, or the current line up from the previous battle. It's far from perfect, but playing a game I haven't paid for I'm expecting some rough edges. This is rougher than most.  To give a scale of how much I enjoyed this game, it would range between 6 and 7.

												This is my first review ever. I am the kind of player who tries not to pay anything as far as free to play games are concerned. I have been playing this game for 3 weeks now.I love puzzle quest and indeed its not possible to dominate or enjoy this game without paying sth. Even for the player who doesnt want to be competitive, he still has to pay sth in order to get room to store his cards. I am not refering to storing extra cards (like having spiderman twice) but only to the cards you can get after playing the for some time. Putting those things aside its a great game. It is probably the best puzzle quest game so far. Its challenging, fun, addictive, and it a game that makes you pause for a little while for your heroes to rest (if you are a F2p player like me). Some people consider that pause a disadvantage. Considering how addictive the game is its best that you pause now and then. Events are fun and even F2P players like me get a chance to win some cards. Maybe i will not get the high level cards P2W players will get but nontheless the feeling of achievement is there. And due to the high requirements to level up heroes i believe  i will be playng this game for a long time with good fun. Plus due to the level cap of heroes i will eventually catch up with those P2W players.I believe spending money to get the 18 euro gold pack will get you the room necessary to store most of the cards you will get in game. Whether or not that will be worth it, its up to you! I certainly haven't regretted spending them.

I'm enjoying this game a lot for what it is, and that's a solid combat RPG with puzzle mechanics.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 11, 2015
												I started this match-3 free-to-play game without putting any money into it, and while the time limitations of such f2p games is in place, it still allowed me to play for stretches of about an hour a few times a day.  I got a nice puzzle fix, and I have to say that, compared to other f2p match-3 puzzle games, I found the reward system for this one giving me that extra little incentive to actually keep coming back to this one.By doing the quest lines I was able to acquire some character covers to upgrade my characters, and earn the Iso-8 which is used to level them up after upgrading, and even some gold which I proceeded to use to pick up a few more cover slots allowing more heroes.  With about 6-9 heroes available in various stages of upgrade, I was able to start in on some phases of the Deadpool dailies, earning Iso-8 more quickly and continuing to upgrade.Joining a random active alliance I began to get meager rewards from the weekly events and start giving it a shot myself.  I obviously did not get very far or do very well, but I did succeed in getting just that little more gold or Iso-8 or hero cover, and the prospect of earning just a little more kept me coming back, as did the continually expanding daily login bonus. (up to day 105 and still going, including a three star hero cover and heroic level random covers to boot.)Once I reached over 200 hours played, I decided to go ahead and support the game itself by spending $50 on it.  I have picked up AAA titles for my consoles for $50 and not spent nearly as much time, both hours-wise or days in a row played, as I have this game.  I have to say that, had I put that money in sooner, I don't believe it would have boosted my performance much in the beginning, but at the point I was at, having finished the story quests for all their repeated rewards and filled my f2p expanded roster, being able to add a dozen more heroes suddenly made my capabilities at this stage much more effective, and the game has just renewed itself in making me want to return to it each day just to see how much I can accomplish this time.If you have the patience, and enjoy match-3 puzzle games, and on top of that if you enjoy the Marvel license, this is a no-brainer.  It can be fun and enjoyable, even without putting any money into it, just don't expect to play it all in one sitting.  Much better as a short-session time waster, and approached as such, can feel very strategic, rewarding, and beneficial.Update: Passed the 900 hour mark, and still playing, still enjoying, still killing time with it.

Posted: February 18, 2015
												Match-three meets Micro-transactions meets CCG mechanics. Free to Play but also Pay to Win.Cons: -Storyline virtually inexistent-Brings nothing new to the genre -Does not delivers especially well what's been done better in other games of the same genre-Worst thing about it? Everything about this game feels like a test of endurance in ''How long will you hold out until you succumb and spend money''. Pros:FreeRecommendations:I would recommend the average consumer to avoid this product, although I have to admit that someone who actively enjoys the feeling of ''outsmarting'' the game design of Free To Play/Pay To Win titles might get a good number of hours of entertainment out of it.Actual length of content:As the game is updated regularly, with game modes coming and going, the actual length depends greatly on the consumer's personal tolerance for that genre and its repetition more than the available  I personnally checked out after less than 3 hours even though I must have spent more than 300 hours on similar titles.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 20
												Seeing all the hate, and having played this game for a long, long, LONG time, I believe I have the knowledge and experience to leave a detailed, comprehensive, and balanced review. I will start by saying that very few of the complaints aren't without merit, which is why I LOVE to HATE this damn game.Recently, D3 GO! released several innovations which increase the fun of playing the game...as well as still maintaining a skewed balancing system that favors the infamous micro-transaction. And I should know...I have made tons of micro-transactions in my long history of playing this game. A little here, some there, maybe a major buy or two (in fact, I think exactly two, LOL) over all that time. And believe me, the micro-part of the transaction can really add up over time. Let's address these new additions first, shall we? Command Points: Not too long ago, D3 GO! added Command Points to the MPQ universe. It was meant to thinly disguise the pay-to-pay (you read that right, not much of a free game if you have to pay to even place, much less win, IMHO) aspects of hero leveling. Here's the issue; if I have to have 250 CPs to take my hero up just one freaking level, it ain't doing jack for me. Especially since CPs are sparingly earned in only the toughtest missions (usually the two top 'boss' style stages of a level and maybe a really tough mission or two.) And you waste so much power and health trying to get one CP that you might as well not even try. And that's if you are running around with a fairly stacked roster!! (Mine is, BTW)     Now a lot of people might say, "Well you can't buy CPs, so it's all fair, and cash don't determine no leveling no more."  Yeah, stupid, except there's an issue with that. Purchasing the largest packages of ISO or Loonies gets you a crapton of CPs...not just for you, but for your whole friggin' Alliance, as well!! Just one Alliance member with really, really, REALLY deep pockets can upset the balance of power in a heartbeat. In addition, only the highest leveled (i.e., pay-to-win) players can actiually breeze through the missions to hit the fourth replay that gets you your damn CP in the first place!! (But the CP drops on those missions is random!! Yeah, no, moron. Count the number of times you actually get the damn CPs. Almost always on the fourth replay.)  Favorites: This feature is straight up bull $#!^. I have issues getting covers for my Jean Grey Pheonix Classic. Ever since getting her years ago (sarcasm) I've only ever once gotten a JGPC cover on a random draw. Now here, my CP and Favorites complaint merges--no matter how many 'Classics' packs I open...there's never a damn JGPC in them!! (You can buy a Classics pack with 20 CPs. Don't expect any--you know--actually useful characters. Same for the Modern Legends packs. And so when the Favorites feature was ntroduced, (which promises increased chances of drawing a 'Bonus' Cover for a Favorited character)  I was all, "Yay!! Now I finally get me some of that Jean Grey!!" And I set her as my only favorite. Yeah, no. Not happening. >_>Bottom Line--Even with a consistent stream of micro-transactions (meaning micro in the truest sense of the word) you will not place better than mid-tier status without forking over massive amounts of cold, hard cash. I really wish Steam would get that 'Mixed' review button out, because that's exactly my feelings on this game--mixed. I like the new innovations, but I hate how they are still balanced towards in-game transactions. I like that new stories are coming out pretty frquently, and new characters are coming out constantly--but don't like that I can never get them until literally months down the road because I am not investing enough to mortgage a house on. I will leave this review with a concise summary of Pros and Cons. If you understand the nature of the game, and expect little in the way of competitive wins, then this game is for you. If you can have fun, and enjoy what successes you do have--and don't get♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥over the losses you do get--this game's for you. If you are willing to work hard to level your characters, and realize you may never get those really fraking cool big canon versions of your characters, then this game is for you.My Meter leans ever so slightly on the Pro side here, and thus the thumbs-up. But it is a very slim recomendation indeed. :/ Pros:Fun to play.Challenging.Great hero variety.New Features like the Champion system, which gives extended life to your lower tiered heroes.Cons:New Hero Slots are expensive as hell. (Best bet--dump loosers like Deadpool, Gwenpool, T-Rex looking thing, etc.)Game is rigged to favor P2W tactics, and not real--you know--strategy.Limited ability to even grind properly, as the scaling of the 'Boss' stages favors P2W.New features slanted towards P2W, thus♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥them of their usefulness to the 96% of 'normal' players. (For example, the 'Heroes-for-Hire' feature is outrageously priced for what you get.)

I will start by saying that very few of the complaints aren't without merit, which is why I LOVE to HATE this damn game.Recently, D3 GO! released several innovations which increase the fun of playing the game...as well as still maintaining a skewed balancing system that favors the infamous micro-transaction. And I should know...I have made tons of micro-transactions in my long history of playing this game. A little here, some there, maybe a major buy or two (in fact, I think exactly two, LOL) over all that time. And believe me, the micro-part of the transaction can really add up over time. Let's address these new additions first, shall we? Command Points: Not too long ago, D3 GO! added Command Points to the MPQ universe. It was meant to thinly disguise the pay-to-pay (you read that right, not much of a free game if you have to pay to even place, much less win, IMHO) aspects of hero leveling. Here's the issue; if I have to have 250 CPs to take my hero up just one freaking level, it ain't doing jack for me. Especially since CPs are sparingly earned in only the toughtest missions (usually the two top 'boss' style stages of a level and maybe a really tough mission or two.) And you waste so much power and health trying to get one CP that you might as well not even try. And that's if you are running around with a fairly stacked roster!! (Mine is, BTW)     Now a lot of people might say, "Well you can't buy CPs, so it's all fair, and cash don't determine no leveling no more."  Yeah, stupid, except there's an issue with that. Purchasing the largest packages of ISO or Loonies gets you a crapton of CPs...not just for you, but for your whole friggin' Alliance, as well!! Just one Alliance member with really, really, REALLY deep pockets can upset the balance of power in a heartbeat. In addition, only the highest leveled (i.e., pay-to-win) players can actiually breeze through the missions to hit the fourth replay that gets you your damn CP in the first place!! (But the CP drops on those missions is random!! Yeah, no, moron. Count the number of times you actually get the damn CPs. Almost always on the fourth replay.)  Favorites: This feature is straight up bull $#!^. I have issues getting covers for my Jean Grey Pheonix Classic. Ever since getting her years ago (sarcasm) I've only ever once gotten a JGPC cover on a random draw. Now here, my CP and Favorites complaint merges--no matter how many 'Classics' packs I open...there's never a damn JGPC in them!! (You can buy a Classics pack with 20 CPs. Don't expect any--you know--actually useful characters. Same for the Modern Legends packs. And so when the Favorites feature was ntroduced, (which promises increased chances of drawing a 'Bonus' Cover for a Favorited character)  I was all, "Yay!! Now I finally get me some of that Jean Grey!!" And I set her as my only favorite. Yeah, no. Not happening. >_>Bottom Line--Even with a consistent stream of micro-transactions (meaning micro in the truest sense of the word) you will not place better than mid-tier status without forking over massive amounts of cold, hard cash. I really wish Steam would get that 'Mixed' review button out, because that's exactly my feelings on this game--mixed. I like the new innovations, but I hate how they are still balanced towards in-game transactions. I like that new stories are coming out pretty frquently, and new characters are coming out constantly--but don't like that I can never get them until literally months down the road because I am not investing enough to mortgage a house on. I will leave this review with a concise summary of Pros and Cons. If you understand the nature of the game, and expect little in the way of competitive wins, then this game is for you. If you can have fun, and enjoy what successes you do have--and don't get♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥over the losses you do get--this game's for you. If you are willing to work hard to level your characters, and realize you may never get those really fraking cool big canon versions of your characters, then this game is for you.My Meter leans ever so slightly on the Pro side here, and thus the thumbs-up. But it is a very slim recomendation indeed. :/ Pros:Fun to play.Challenging.Great hero variety.New Features like the Champion system, which gives extended life to your lower tiered heroes.Cons:New Hero Slots are expensive as hell. (Best bet--dump loosers like Deadpool, Gwenpool, T-Rex looking thing, etc.)Game is rigged to favor P2W tactics, and not real--you know--strategy.Limited ability to even grind properly, as the scaling of the 'Boss' stages favors P2W.New features slanted towards P2W, thus♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥them of their usefulness to the 96% of 'normal' players. (For example, the 'Heroes-for-Hire' feature is outrageously priced for what you get.)

												This is one of the best F2P games I've ever played, so much so I've bought a 20 dollar pack if only to support the Devs, not to make things easier for me. The game is balanced enough to enjoy on your own, with enough events or daily tasks to let you get packs with a wide variety of heros, seriously the selection of heros you can get are pretty impressive, like you got the classics like Wolverine, Mr Fantastic, Iron Man, the Hulk. But what about Devilsaur, Howard the Duck, Squirrel Girl, and of course the always awesome Deadpool, so awesome that he is running the daily quests, nice.This game clearly was built with love, the devs put so much heart into this game that this does not feel like a cheap cash grab. I highly recommand this game for people who either need a quick game, on a budget, a puzzle game fan, love marvel, or just want something fun in general to play. Devs, ya did good, and I appauld you for not going the route of many F2Ps
